title: Management of Hospitality and Real Estate Businesses
description: HTMG1010 is an introductory course that takes a macro-level view of the hospitality, tourism, and real estate industries. The contents are geared towards students who have little to no industry experience but have expressed an interest in pursuing a career in the industry or a related field.The primary objectives of this course are three-folded. First, this course discusses the historical developments, business models, and management structures of lodging, restaurant, managed service, casino/gaming, meetings / conventions / expositions, recreation, club, theme park, cruise, airline, and other hospitality and tourism organizations. Second, experiential learning opportunities are provided to help students understand the operations of hospitality organizations and the importance of service quality. The course also introduces students to the business world of real estate, including terminology, transaction process, issues, players and activities in the real estate industry. Third, the course prepares students for future development of leadership competencies with descriptions of the key management functions and the characteristics and practices of leaders and managers. Students will also learn about some of the most important business / tourism ethics principles and corporate social responsibilities.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students are expected to achieve the following knowledge, skill, and attitude outcomes: 1. Knowledge: • understand the many facets of the global hospitality and tourism industry; • build a working knowledge of industry-specific terminology and management practices; • understand the terms, issues and topics in commercial real estate; • understand the complexities and challenges that face industry managers in today’s dynamic environment; and • describe the career opportunities available in the industry.   2. Skills: • identify the different product offerings and market segments, key trends and issues impacting the management practices used in the global hospitality and tourism industry; • describe and interpret information and data relevant to the global hospitality, tourism, and real estate industries; • describe the real estate development process;  • demonstrate effective communication and presentation skills; • work effectively independently and with others both in classroom discussions and in practical learning; and • self-appraise and reflect on practice.  3. Attitudes: • develop an appreciation for service excellence and a positive service orientation; • respect for human dignity and the environment; • develop a global outlook and social awareness; • develop an awareness of the fundamental ethics principles; and • acknowledge and follow the Global Code of Ethics for Tourism as promoted by the United Nations World Tourism Organization (UNWTO).

title: Hospitality Financial Accounting
description: This course is designed to provide students with a basic understanding of hospitality financial accounting concepts. The emphasis of the course is to use accounting information in making managerial decisions and to prepare and understand hospitality financial statements. Overall objectives include developing an understanding of major components of the Hospitality Balance Sheet, the Hospitality Income Statement and the Hospitality Statement of Cash Flows and are able to interpret the financial information presented in these statements. Furthermore, students will develop a comprehension of basic concepts of financial analysis, the use of key ratios, and the essentials of managing assets such as cash, receivables, inventory, fixed assets,intangibles, and major liabilities and related accounts such as payroll, accounts payable,and long-term debt.

title: Hospitality Managerial Account'g
description: This course is designed to provide students with a thorough understanding of hospitality managerial accounting concepts. The emphasis of the course is to learn how to use accounting as a managerial tool to improve operational efficiency and profitability of hospitality firms. Students should understand and apply a variety of analytical models of hospitality operation and investment such as forecasting, pricing, revenue and profit optimization, and budgeting. Specific topics will include financial analyses of hospitality firms; cost structures; Activity-Based Costing (ABC); Cost Volume Profit (CVP)analysis; yield management concepts; short-term and long-term forecasting models; operating and capital budgeting and the fundamental differences between capital and operating leases.

title: International Experience
description: An international experience is a personal and professional growth opportunity for students to interact with a culture other than their own, to improve their cultural understanding, and to prepare for working more effectively in diverse cultural and business environments. International experience has been shown to increase graduates’ employability. It is particularly important in global industries such as the hospitality and real estate industries where communication skills, problem-solving skills, and service orientation are crucial for career success. This course is designed to encourage students to participate in international experience activities prior to graduation. These activities include overseas exchange, internship, study tour, volunteer/service learning projects, and other international learning activities.
outcome: Students are expected to achieve the following learning outcomes via participating in international experiences:  • Develop a stronger cross-cultural sensitivity and a global perspective; • Gain experience of communicating and collaborating with students and/or other stakeholders abroad; • Improve teamwork and problem-solving skills; • Increase leadership confidence and competency; • Improve abilities to reflect on personal experiences.

title: Food and Beverage Management
description: This is a course that examines the principles of food and beverage management. It begins with an overview of the food service industry and the specific disciplines of food service distribution. Current issues in food safety and sanitation procedures that affect managerial decisions in hospitality industry will be discussed. Detailed considerations are given to the components of the food service system: marketing, menu planning, purchasing, logistical support, guest service, controls, and quality assurance. Students will also learn through visits to restaurant operations, analyse the restaurant's concept (market), organization, ownership,management, physical structure, staff, front- and back-of-the-house operations, and fiscal integrity.
outcome: Business Concepts and Functions This course has two missions and they are aligned with an eight course paradigm: 1/ To enable students to discover all aspects in opening, running and owning a restaurant, from an entrepreneur perspective, and 2/ Students who would like to be future leaders in the F&B and hospitality industries, learn how do senior executives in strategic business units manage their business with the assistance of “P&L” (profit & loss statement)  Analytical Skills (Finance) The bread and butter of F&B business are sales, gross profit, payroll control and gross operating profit. To support student’s learning, we share with students: the breakdown of “top line” with cover check; how to identify managerial/ operational problems from a P&L statement and come up with improvement plan; application of Solver Model to maximize production profit, and to plan appropriate labour coverage  Professional Skills (Operations, Marketing) The spectrum of F&B learning is wide, from terminology of “mise-en-place” & conventional system; various cooking methods; HACCP; environmental health; carbon emission trade; facilities plan; beauty of technology - “sous vide” and “liaison froide”; to guerrilla marketing. Students should understand that the inventions and systems are custom-made to assist today’s management to protect /benefit our stakeholders at all cost.  Attitude/Values (Human Resources) To arouse students’ interests, to embrace learning, students must be passionate about F&B. Students will experience sensory evaluation of classical cuisine and learn basic food and wine pairing knowledge.  F&B is a Human Capital Business and students will be tested individually, as well as in a team. Mid-term includes a team cooking test in our demonstration kitchen with time constraint.  Working with people to achieve goal is the prerequisite of future leader.

Knowledge of how to determine restaurant concepts, menu design, prepare labor staffing guides, work schedules and facility layouts; 3. Knowledge of service management and tools used to measure customer satisfaction, use of the menu as a control and a marketing tool; and 4. Ability to apply control procedures to the purchasing, receiving, and storage activities.

title: Summer Internship I
description: In order for students in the Major to apply theory to application, they are required to gain hands-on experience and to participate in industry-related internship experiences throughout their study, preferably during two summers. Summer Internship I is a course to monitor students in their first summer internship training. The educational objectives can be achieved through industry activities that are either operational based and/or project based. The Internship Program allows students to gain a realistic expectation of the hospitality and tourism operations. All internship experiences must be approved by the School. Thus, for students who choose to self-place, it is his/her responsibility to seek prior written approval from the Director before the internship begins.
outcome: To enable students to apply what they have learned in the classroom to solve real-world business problems related to the hospitality and tourism industry; To develop a good understanding of the different aspects of the hospitality and tourism operations in Hong Kong and abroad; and To strengthen and build characters, and instil professional attitude and passion in students towards the hospitality and tourism industry.
syllabus: Hotel and Tourism Management majors are required to gain hands-on experience and to participate in industry-related projects during the summers of their second and third years of attendance. The internship can be either operational based or project based. The School has developed relationships with employers who consistently offer summer internships. A student though must seek approval from the School if they would like to arrange their own internship. The program carries credit (HTMG2900 & HTMG3900) which is a requirement for graduation. Both Internship I and II serve as pre-requisites for HTMG4900. That is, the enrolment in HTMG4900 is subject to the successful completion of the two summer internships requirements.   Before the internship, all students are required to participate in the pre-internship workshops prior to their first summer break. Pre-internship training will be provided for students to acquire the business etiquette, resume writing, interview skills and interpersonal skills required for succeeding in a workplace.

title: Management of Lodging Facilities
description: This course introduces students to the principles of hotel management. It contains an overview of organization, function, and management of lodging operation. The discussion will focus on the inter-relationships among stakeholders of a lodging facility - guests, managers, owners and employees. Special emphasis will be on the integration of the various departments of a hotel facility, i.e. Rooms, Front Desk, Sales, Food and Beverage (F&B), Purchasing, Housekeeping, Engineering and Maintenance, etc., to ensure customer satisfaction while maximizing the return on investment. Students will be exposed to computing applications specific to the hotel industry. Hotel security, guest safety as well as total quality issues will also be discussed.

syllabus: to provide students with the skills and knowledge necessary to successfully operate a full-service hotel.  -- to provide students with the fundamental “ hows” and “ whys “ of management in the lodging industry. --to cover all key departments in a lodging property so that students will have a better understanding of how different departments fit together and contribute to its success.  --to promote critical thinking among students by exposing them to theories, research based materials, actual case studies pertaining to hotel management.  --to train students on acquiring the essential skills and knowledge of managing the front office and the various management systems for the successful operation of the property.

title: Hospitality Organization Behaviour
description: All organizations are faced with “people issues.” Why do people think, feel, and act in certain ways in the workplace? How do you manage people effectively to achieve the organizational objectives? More important, how do you continue to manage people effectively when the organization is going through significant strategic/structural changes? This course draws upon the theoretical insights and empirical evidence from the Organizational Behavior (OB) research and introduces students to the applications of psychological and behavioral approaches to designing effective human resource management (HRM) policies and practices. The course provides a systematic overview of fundamental OB concepts, theories, and applications in the context of hospitality, tourism, and real estate businesses. We will discuss a variety of topics at three levels. First, we will study how individuals differ in their personality traits, values, attitudes, emotions, perceptions, and motivations. Second, we will examine how people interact with one another and work in groups and teams. Topics range from team dynamics, group decision making, power and influence, to conflict management. Leadership theories and practices will also be discussed. Third, we will discuss how organizational-level factors such as organizational culture and change affect attitudes, behaviors, and work performances of employees. The OB concepts and theories are closely related to HRM. Through the course students will learn how to apply OB theories to improve HRM effectiveness in a variety of areas, e.g., job design and analysis, employee recruitment and selection, training and socialization, employee performance appraisal, compensation and benefits, and organizational culture formation and maintenance. Students will also learn what characteristics, behaviors, attitudes, and competencies define good leadership and how to ensure successful organizational changes through effectively motivating employees. Overall, this course explains why and how individuals and groups are motivated to do their jobs and helps students develop critical leadership skills to manage people and organizational changes.Blended-mode class section is available for this course. Please refer to the “Class Notes” of the blended-mode class section for details.
outcome: • To understand major concepts and theories in OB • To apply OB concepts and theories to human resource management practices in hospitality and real estate organizations • To understand characteristics, behaviors, attitudes, and competencies that define good leadership • To apply OB concepts and theories to managing changes in organizations • To develop critical thinking, problem solving, communication, and teamwork skills
syllabus: This is an introductory course that integrates organizational behavior (OB) insights with HRM practices in hospitality and real estate organizations. We live in an organizational world. Studying OB (i.e., to understand how employees and managers behave and why they behave the way they do) helps you succeed in your careers and helps your organizations succeed. This course will help by covering a wide variety of OB topics such as personality traits, perception and decision making, motivation, team dynamics, leadership, power and influence, conflict resolution, and organizational culture and change.

title: Hospitality Real Estate
description: This course is designed to encourage students to think about hospitality properties as real estate. The two fundamental markets that are relevant to commercial real estate investment analysis are space market and asset market. The former refers to the market for the right to use real estate (e.g., land and buildings) and the latter refers to the market for the ownership of real estate assets. This course focuses on the space market. Specific objectives are: to recognize the importance of real estate space market in the overall real estate system, which involves an understanding of supply, demand and rent in the space market; to understand the fundamental factors of location of economic activities; and to learn real estate market analysis for providing advice to real estate decision makers.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: - Describe the key concepts and fundamental importance of space market in the overall real estate system. - Apply theoretical frameworks to real world, especially hospitality real estate industry. - Critically analyze the real estate space market to make informed real estate decisions. - Demonstrate capability in using quantitative skills. - Develop creative thinking, self-managed ability, team work spirit, analytical and communication skills through class discussions and project presentations.
syllabus: It is a one-semester course to provide a conceptual and theoretical foundation for real estate space market with the applications to hospitality industry. This course primarily examines urban economics, which is the main discipline for studying real estate space market. Two main topics to be covered are the principles of urban economics and real estate market analysis.  The principles of urban economics deal with central place theory, system of cities, fundamental factors of location, concept of rent, highest and best use, bid-rent curve, and formation of land market.   The real estate market analysis deals with the analysis of market supply and demand indicators, and the formal model of space market equilibrium dynamics and cyclicality.

title: Service Business and Hospitality Law
description: This course seeks to provide an introduction to the institutions, doctrines and methodology of the law in the context of the hospitality business. To this end, the course will begin with an examination of the legal system of the Hong Kong SAR before proceeding to encompass a selection of topics in business and hospitality law such as the law relating to contract,agency, employment and the sale of goods and torts (e.g., negligence and occupier's liability).

title: Law for Hospitality and Real Estate Industry
description: Knowing laws that govern the hospitality and real estate industries is no longer a luxury. It is a knowledge that every manager must acquire to protect their companies from unnecessary fines, lawsuits and negative publicity. This module focuses on the laws relating to the hospitality and real estate industry in Hong Kong. It provides students with the essential knowledge on legal principles that are important for the practice within the hospitality and real estate industry. The course will introduce a wide range of legal topics including legal system, company law, contract law, tort law and land law.

title: Travel and Tourism Management
description: This course is an overview of the travel and tourism industry's management issues, professional opportunities, marketing concepts, planning and development strategies and its relevance to the geography of travel, transportation issues and travel service. Different aspects of tourism, including origin and destination flow models, tourist profiles, demand and supply interaction, and barriers to travel are explored and analysed. Emerging concepts such aseco-tourism, heritage tourism, adventure tourism, sustainable tourism, etc., will also be examined.
outcome: Business concepts and functions  -- Understand the components of both demand-side and supply-side of tourism and the associated difficulties and issues -- Understand the concept of marketing for tourism and related techniques  Analytical skills  -- Compare the components of the travel and tourism system -- Analyze the future development of the tourism system  Professional Skills  -- Apply the knowledge acquired in Hong Kong as well as other regions in the world  Attitude/Values -- Appreciate the economic impacts of tourism activities
syllabus: This course is an overview of the travel and tourism industry’s management issues, professional opportunities, marketing concepts, planning and development strategies and its relevance to the geography of travel, transportation issues and travel services. Different aspects of tourism, including destination attractiveness, tourist profiles, demand and supply interaction, and barriers to travel are explored and analyzed.  The contents of this course are three-fold. Firstly, basic concepts will be reviewed with reference to the textbook, suggested readings and class discussion. Secondly, the application of academic concepts acquired from this course as well as other related courses will be explored through the real life projects. Lastly, leaders from the travel industry will be invited to share the industry update with the students.  Having successfully completed this course, students should be able to:  • Understand the components of both demand-side and supply-side of tourism; • Appreciate the economic, social and cultural impacts of tourism activities; • Analyze the interplay among the components of the travel and tourism system; • Apply the concepts of marketing to tourism; • Explore the future development of the tourism system;  • Draw on experiences of Hong Kong and other regions of the world in reviewing current issues in tourism; and  • Explain the Global Code of Ethics for Tourism and ethical conduct for practitioners in the industry.

title: Service and Hospitality Quality Management
description: This course is an analysis of management issues related to service culture, quality control and organizational performance in the hospitality industry. It introduces principles of microeconomics and how they apply to managers of enterprises associated with the hospitality industry. Emphasis will be placed on issues relating to the total quality management in the service industries. The interactions among affect, cognition, behaviours, and environment events that are important to the service operation of hospitality industry will also be examined.
outcome: Business Concepts and Functions Objectives of this course are three folds: *To develop students’ understanding of the strategic importance of quality in global competition and the historical evolutions of quality management *To equip students with the latest theories, concepts and techniques in the area of service quality management for the hospitality industry *To demonstrate how quality management theories, concepts and tools can be used to improve quality and customers satisfaction  Analytical Skills Implementing quality doesn’t mean pleasing client at the expense of company, baseline assessment triangle should be balanced - internal customers, external customers, and financial goal.   To access quality system and its effectiveness, students learn how leadership, customer satisfaction, human resources utilization, information & analysis, quality assurance of commodities, quality result, and strategic quality planning should interact. These assist to redefine strategic goals of business units, and help senior executives to allocate proper resources.  Professional Skills Company cannot attain goal without the understanding of quality. An organization’s soul is apparent when vision, mission and core values capture the uniqueness.  Goals can be measured are placed on a balanced score card (BSC). An organization’s future is built on intangible assets, BSC adds strategic dimension to our students, our future leader.  Students learn how to turn quality management into powerful business weapon.  Attitude/Values To be a visionary leader, students learn how to “lead quality”, to know oneself before one can lead others. We share with students the paradigm of classical management and new leadership; it is the foundation to continuous quality improvement.  Students will be tested individually, as well as in a group project. They will learn the leadership secret, being accountable to your action, people and organization (group).
syllabus: -To develop students’ understanding of the strategic importance of quality in global competition and the historical evolutions of quality management.  -To equip students with the latest theories, concepts and techniques in the area of service quality management for the hospitality industry.  -To demonstrate how quality management theories, concepts and tools can be used to improve quality and the creation of delighted and appreciative customers. -To develop students’ appreciation of the importance of quality in relation to their personal life.

title: Human Resources Planning and Staffing for Hospitality Business
description: This course focuses on managing people in the workplace. It addresses issues of human resources planning and staffing and substantive issues or situations to be faced as future hospitality managers, including the relationship between selection and recruitment, compensation and benefit activities and job design, motivation, and reward structure. Students will also learn the major theoretical and practical issues associated with programme design,development, implementation, and evaluation of hospitality human resources programme.

title: Real Estate Finance
description: This course exposes students to concepts, theories and industry practice in real estate finance which is one of the largest and most important components of the financial system. It also introduces valuation and appraisal methods used for real estate finance and investment decision making. The primary goal of this course is to help students acquire the knowledge and develop the analytical skills of real estate finance, including the institutions and instruments used to finance residential and commercial real estate. It is of particular use to students who are interested in working the real estate development, brokerage, mortgage banking and investment banking industries. The main topics covered in the course are mortgage products, mortgage banking, secondary mortgage market and mortgage-backed securities (MBS), financial leverage and commercial real estate finance.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: - Differentiate and analyze different types of real estate (commercial, industrial, residential) - Identify different types of mortgages available in the marketplace and explain their characteristics - Understand and apply generally recognized investment valuation techniques to real estate  - Calculate fixed-rate mortgages (FRM) and adjustable-rate mortgages (ARM) (e.g. monthly payment, amortization and effective borrowing cost) and make a rational choice among various mortgages based on the calculations - Identify the major players in the secondary mortgage market and explain how the market is functioning - Understand and be able to explain the structure and the role of securitization in the property market - Compare different sources of commercial real estate financing (both the debt side and the equity side) and analyze how leverage affects risk and return - Conduct real estate investment analysis and make investment recommendations accordingly
syllabus: - Legal foundation of real estate finance - Mathematics of real estate finance - Mortgage instruments: Fixed rate mortgages - Mortgage instruments: Adjustable rate mortgages - Incremental borrowing cost, loan refinancing - Residential mortgage banking - Mortgage origination and underwriting - Secondary mortgage market - Mortgage-backed securities

title: Hospitality Sales Force Management
description: Students will learn through class discussion and practical application on how to establish a working sales office system for hotels and other sectors in the service industry. Concepts addressed include developing product and service knowledge, seeking out prospects, applying selling techniques and improving communication skill. Unique characteristics of the service industry will be stressed. Students will understand the effective use of a variety of marketing communication media, including advertising, sales promotion, and public relation.

title: Financial Management and Cost Control for Hospitality Organizations
description: This course applies accounting, finance, and cost control principles to the hospitality industry. The focus of this course is to provide future hospitality managers with the ability to add value and to handle the unique problems regarding financial management and cost control in this industry. Special emphasis will be placed on the estimation of cash flows and asset management related to the hospitality industry. It also provides a detailed analysis of food,beverage, and labour cost control.

title: Franchising and Multi-Unit Management in the Hospitality Industry
description: This course discusses the relationship between franchisor and franchisee, advantages and disadvantages of using franchising in the hospitality industry, and the structure of and services offered by franchisors in the hospitality industry. Actual cases of franchising arrangements in the hospitality industry will be used to illustrate the concept. In addition, the organization,administration and evaluation of existing and changing practices, concepts and theories in multi-unit management in the hospitality industry will be examined.

title: Talent Development
description: Owing to the fact that becoming skilled at training and development is no longer a function of just human resources professionals, managers and leaders are responsible for the training and development of their employees also. This course is designed to facilitate students’ understanding of the frameworks and conceptual underpinnings of training & development (T&D), and their application of the latest human resources development tools and techniques in addressing T&D issues. The formulation and implementation of effective policies, systems and programs for the T&D of manpower at all levels of the hospitality operations are emphasized.

title: International Hospitality Business and Management
description: This course provides an overview of the contemporary issues in the international business environment facing multinational service firms in the hospitality and tourism industry. These issues include such topics as: global strategy formulation and implementation; technology challenges; diversity in customers and employees; political and legal concerns; and effective organizational structures for long-term survival and success.

title: Information Technology for Service Industry
description: This course introduces students from a management perspective to the state-of-the-art technology-based systems used in the service industry, which enhance guest service and support management decision-making. Key issues in information-technology investment and management will be explored.

title: Marketing Research and Customer Relationship Management in the Service Industry
description: This course provides a basic understanding to students on collection, processing, analysis and applications of marketing data in the service industry. The course is divided into two parts, namely, Customer Relationship management (CRM) and Marketing Research. CRM covers the recent trend in data driven marketing and social media marketing to use secondary data (e.g. customer transaction data, internet data) to understand customers, and design strategies to sell the right products to right customers at the right time. Marketing Research covers the traditional survey methodology and the use of primary data to support decision making in marketing. Our approach to CRM and marketing research is more on the concept, design, and applications instead of mathematics or statistics. No formula is required to understand the material, and students use Excel in data analysis. Moreover, we will invite experts from the industry to share the current practices of marketing research and CRM in both Hong Kong and China.

title: Seminar on Cruise Line Management
description: Course approaches the cruise industry as a unique combination of the hospitality, tourism, marketing and shipping industries. Course objectives are designed to familiarize students with the structure and operation of the cruise industry and related leisure/tourism segments of overnight and fast ferries; river cruises; sail cruises; gaming boats; and passenger/cargo operations. Having successfully completed this course, students will be able to understand the evolution of the modern cruise industry and the factors involved in its growth, to identify the market segments and their relationship to itinerary, onboard product and ship design; to know the major cruise lines and their target markets and operating areas; to be familiar with the impact of ship designconstraints, SOLAS (Safety of Life at Sea) and MARPOL (Maritime Pollution Regulations), and other regulatory requirements on onboard product, itinerary, and ship cost and finance. Also, students will become familiar with the economic and social impact of cruise shipping in home ports, turn-around ports and ports-of-call.

title: Wine Culture and Appreciation
description: Wine has its roots customs, traditions and history. It occupies an important place in culture and life of people worldwide. Starting in the 1990s, there is a great surge of interest in wine across the globe. Wine has been a significant element in social gathering and business meetings. Wine becomes the challenge for hospitality operators to meet the needs of increasing sophisticated tastes of consumers. To be an effective hospitality manager, knowledge of the alcoholic products, particularly wine, is essential. The ability to taste, understand, evaluate, and articulate wine in a clear, easily understood manner is key to meeting customers' needs and at the same time, increasing wine sales and profitability. The course is designed to expose students wine label terminology, wine appreciation, and learn the principles on how to choose wines to pair with many different foods. The topics include cultural history of wine, the role of alcohol in society; major wine regions, grape varieties, vintages and winemaking process, sensory training and comparative tasting methods to help build students' ability to discern distinct flavours from major types of wine and build strong base for lifelong wine appreciation and enhance their quality of life.

title: Airline and Airport Management
description: Airline and Airport contribute significantly to tourism and the economy but both aircraft and airport require substantial amount of initial investment. In this course, students will learn the airline and airport from both operational and business perspective, its regulatory framework, how it contributes to tourism and the economy , and the related contemporary issues such as low cost carriers, environmental protection, and sustainability issues. The content includes the role played by international and local aviation authorities, regulatory framework, airport business, airport operation, air cargo, airline operation, airticket pricing, selection of aircraft, airline marketing and financing. After taking the course, students should have good knowledge on this business and prepare them for working in the aviation field.

title: Shopping Mall Investment and Management
description: Shopping mall business is an attractive business in Hong Kong. There are many leading shopping malls in the region and it generates stable rental income and attractive returns to the property developers. Property developers differentiate their shopping malls from their competitors and it forms a significant part of investment (called investment properties) on the Statement of Financial Positions and has significant impact on the Income Statement. This course aims at introducing students to the management and investment perspective of shopping mall business and how it contributes to tourism. It includes design of a shopping mall, its marketing, leasing process, customer services, car park management, investment return analysis, investment value calculation and the regulatory framework. Ethical considerations facing property developers and investors will also be discussed. After taking this course, students should have good understanding of the shopping mall business and allow them to work in the real estate management and investment field.

title: Revenue Management
description: This course provides an introduction to both the theory and the practice of revenue management. Revenue management is the process of improving corporate revenue through the implementation of Strategic Pricing and Inventory Controls. In a simple way, the concept of revenue management is to sell the right room to the right customer at the right price at the right time. The purpose of this course is to help students get insights into the management of the Rooms Division area of the hotel operations. This course includes the explanation of the best practices, techniques and strategies currently used in the hospitality industry by either front office managers, room division directors and / or revenue managers. This course will focus on the important elements leading up to effective revenue management – market segmentation, demand forecasting, inventory & price management and distribution channel management. The course will also emphasize the real-life application of the revenue management concepts learned in class through a series of guest lectures from industry experts. Students who plan to take the course should have knowledge of basic hotel performance indices such as occupancy percentage, ADR, and RevPAR.
outcome: In completion of the course, students should be able to: - Describe the history and concepts of revenue management. - Identify and describe the various room inventory distribution channels currently used in the hospitality industry. - Describe the principles of room inventory and rate management applied across the room inventory distribution channels. - Describe the principles, methodology and practices of yield and revenue management in the hospitality industry. - Recognize the use of forecasting and overbooking in reference to room availability by applying the ratios and formulas managers use to forecast room availability - Identify and describe various techniques and strategies used for pricing rooms in a hotel environment - Understand the typical job responsibilities and reporting relationships of Revenue Managers.
syllabus: Teaching methods for the course may include lectures, class discussions, case studies, and excel assignments. Guest speakers who will contribute to the student learning experience by providing industry and/or empirical perspective(s), as well as “real” industry application may be invited for the course.

title: Land Conversion Process and Development Control
requirements: Prerequisite of HTMG students: HTMG3030/4060/4100;Prerequisite of non-HTMG students: FINA2010/3080
description: Land improvement refers to investments that make land more usable for humans. Prior to the development of its industrial and commercial activities, Hong Kong was once an agrarian society with a large amount of active agricultural land. The growth of Hong Kong’s economy is accompanied with large areas of agricultural land, with fish ponds and farmlands, being developed into other uses. Land conversion process and development control has significant economic and social implications for all stakeholders involved. This course is designed to address two major topics: lease control and statutory control during land conversion and development processes. The course provides a foundation for understanding land development. Landowners and developers of all sizes typically aim to maximize profits, minimize risks and control cash flow. These objectives require landowners and developers to design optimal plans for local markets and meet local legal and administrative requirements and procedures. This course introduces Hong Kong’s land tenure system and development control and helps students understand the geographical characteristics of real estate properties in Hong Kong that have been developed into different uses over time. Students will also learn about the interplay between development processes and local conditions.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students should be able to: o Understand the land tenure system in Hong Kong and apply the knowledge of land use control in real estate settings in a global context; o Know the two dimensional development control: lease control and statutory control in Hong Kong, the role of various authorities in the land development control; o Understand and apply town planning, land control and development knowledge to delivering excellent services to potential clients; o Develop creative thinking and problem solving skills relevant to land development issues; o self-managed ability, leadership skills, team work spirit, analytical and communicative skills and oral presentation skills that are appropriate in a variety of investment scenarios through case studies and group projects; o Identify and address ethical issues in both land investment and development settings.
syllabus: • Land leasehold system • Town planning • Development control in Hong Kong • Statutory control in Hong Kong • Current land administration and development control

title: Introduction to Real Estate Investments
requirements: Prerequisite for HTMG students: HTMG3030, 4100;Prerequisite for non-HTMG students: FINA2010, 3080
description: This course provides the most fundamental concepts, principles and techniques useful for making investment decisions regarding commercial real estate assets. Important subjects such as discounted cash flow (DCF), net present value (NPV), valuation of property price, use of debt and tax investment analysis will be covered. Adequate time will be dedicated to learn how to build a fully integrated property financial model which is the most typical analytical tool to evaluate investment performance and help decision making. Students will walk through the financial details relevant to a property and create five-year/ten-year cash flow projections. Familiarity with excel will be a requirement of this course. To enhance the mastery of the lecture and improve applications to real world practice, a number of case studies and practical exercises that help to reinforce the financial modelling techniques necessary for financial decision making will be selected.

title: Hospitality and Real Estate Design Thinking
description: Hospitality is about engaging people through friendly, genuine experiences. Today, the notion “hospitality” has gone beyond lodging and food & beverage businesses and been recognized as a key aspect of many other types of service businesses, e.g., tourism, retail, healthcare, recreation, or even real estate and property management services. Moreover, hospitality is not just about creating memorable, “front-of-the-stage” customer experiences. It is also about creating warm, welcoming, “back-of-the-stage” work experiences for employees. With “experience” as a central theme, a key question for organizations is “How to create the best experience for customers as well as employees?” This course prepares students to answer this question by applying Design Thinking methodology to hospitality experience design for customers and employees in service businesses. Design Thinking is a process for creatively and systematically solving problems by putting people and their needs first. It emphasizes deep understanding of user experience and empathetic, iterative, and non-linear processes of imagination and idea generation. In this course, students will learn about the fundamental design thinking processes and tools and apply them to practical projects aimed to incorporate the notion of hospitality in design thinking for hospitality and real estate businesses. Students will work in teams on projects assigned by a service business for the purpose to design/improve customer and/or employee experiences in specific operational areas. Students will be guided through the processes of understanding experiences, building empathy with customers/employees, defining problems, collecting and analyzing data, generating solutions, and testing solutions. You are expected to develop a deeper understanding of hospitality spirit from a design thinking perspective, gain hands-on experience in service design tasks, enhance problem-solving abilities, and improve teamwork and communication skills.

title: Quantitative Methods for Real Estate
description: The evidence-based policy and practice is of importance in real estate field. The best evidence, which can only be derived from an excellent research, is not only to enhance our understanding, but also to convince others. In the real estate practice, people may ask, “Does the household income affect the property price?” “Should a property located at higher floor command higher price?” The answer can be “yes” or “no” due to a number of factors affecting the price of a property. The empirical evidence is thus needed to convince others.This module focuses on quantitative methods in real estate. It provides students with the fundamental knowledge on conducting real estate research that involves analysis of quantitative data. This course introduces a wide variety of quantitative techniques and tools to analyse the property price. Key topics include hedonic pricing model, managing data, regression analysis and forecasting.

title: Fundamental Research Methodology for Hospitality and Real Estate
description: This course provides students with a strong foundation in the conceptualization and operationalization of research, how to design a research project and ‘hands-on’ skills in the utilization of different research methods. Students will be exposed to a wide range of qualitative and quantitative research methods. Topics to be covered in qualitative research methods include sampling, collection techniques (e.g. in-depth interview, focus group interview, content analysis, etc.) and interpreting qualitative data (e.g. qualitative data analysis procedures and coding). Topics to be covered in quantitative research methods include sampling methods, data collection instruments, survey development, descriptive statistics, inferential statistics (e.g. t-test, regression, analysis of variance, correlations, chi-square, etc.), and data mining. Intellectual and methodological debates will be discussed in order to assist students to develop informed opinions and a critical appreciation for other’s research.

title: Managing Customer Experience and Relationship in Service Industry
description: This course provides an in-depth understanding to students on how to effectively manage customer experience during service encounters and build long-term customer relationship with mutual benefits in the service industry. Students will learn key concepts, theories and models of services marketing, experience management and Customer Relationship Management (CRM) through a mix of lectures/guest lectures, class discussions, case analyses and experiential-learning activities.
outcome: On successfully completing this course, students should be able to: 1. To understand the unique challenge of services marketing and experience management 2. To understand the process of service design, service delivery and service recovery 3. To appreciate the need for relationship management and other issues such as managing supply and demand and managing service quality. 4. To understand the CRM process and applications in the service industry and critically evaluate the effectiveness of CRM strategies
syllabus: Topics including: - Consumer behavior in a service context - Designing and managing service processes - Balancing demand and productivity capacity - Crafting the service environment  - The Gaps model in service design and delivery - Managing relationship and building loyalty - Loyalty programs - Complain handling and service recovery  - CRM process, application and strategies for the service industry
required_readings: 1. Wirtz. J, & Lovelock, C. Essentials of Services Marketing. Essex: Pearson Education Ltd. 2018 2. Kumar, V. & Reinartz, W. Customer Relationship Management: Concept, Strategy, and Tools. Second Edition. Springer. 2012 [Electronic resource].

title: Overseas Study Trip: Understand Impact of Hospitality and Tourism from A Local Perspective
description: This course is centered on a theme-based five-day or one-week overseas study trip to a selected destination. Students are expected to explore local hospitality/tourism business practices and examine the multi-dimensional impacts of the increasingly global hospitality/tourism industry on local community and environment. The course is designed to increase students’ international and experiential learning opportunities. Destinations and themes may differ across academic terms when the course is offered. In principle, the course addresses both exploratory and analytical/evaluative themes. Exploratory themes may cover such issues as local culture, food, hospitality/tourism trends, hospitality history, eco-tourism, heritage tourism, local events/festivals, to name just a few. Analytical/Evaluative themes, on the other hand, require students to understand and evaluate local hospitality/tourism organizations’ practices in areas such as sustainable (“green”) operations, branding/marketing, service quality management, business strategies, and/or corporate social responsibility initiatives. The trip aims to help students gain in-depth and context-specific knowledge of industry practices. In terms of pedagogical methods, the course consists of pre-trip, during-trip, and after-trip learning activities. Pre-trip seminars prepare students for a better understanding of the theme and the destination. Field trips, company visits, and/or local university visits are arranged during the trip. Students are required to keep a travel journal and also complete a group report documenting their findings and thoughts about the study theme. Overall, this course integrates traveling with learning, seeing with thinking, knowledge of global operations with awareness of local contexts. Through learning and sharing, students are encouraged to reflect on their own values and experiences, develop a deeper sensitivity to cultural diversity, and form a better understanding of how hospitality/tourism affects local environment, economy, and culture.

title: Summer Internship II
description: In order for students in the Major to apply theory to application, they are required to gain hands-on experience and to participate in industry-related internship experiences throughout their study, preferably during summers. Summer Internship II is a course to monitor students in their second summer internship training. The objectives of the internship program are to 1) To provide management training opportunities for students to apply what they have learned in the classroom to solving real-world business problems related to the hospitality and tourism industry; 2) To develop a good understanding of the different aspects of the hospitality and tourism operations in Hong Kong and abroad; and 3) To strengthen and build character and instill professional attitude and passion in students towards the hospitality and tourism industry. Students will develop their analytical and problem solving skills by assuming the role of the manager, to offer probable recommendations/solutions to the operational problem that they encounter in the internship. All internship experiences must be approved by the School. Thus, for students who choose to self-place, it is his/her responsibility to seek prior written approval from the Director before the internship begins.
outcome: To enable students to apply what they have learned in the classroom to solve real-world business problems related to the hospitality and tourism industry; To develop a good understanding of the different aspects of the hospitality and tourism operations in Hong Kong and abroad; and To strengthen and build characters, and instil professional attitude and passion in students towards the hospitality and tourism industry.
syllabus: Hotel and Tourism Management majors are required to gain hands-on experience and to participate in industry-related projects during the summers of their second and third years of attendance. The internship can be either operational based or project based. The School has developed relationships with employers who consistently offer summer internships. A student though must seek approval from the School if they would like to arrange their own internship. The program carries credit (HTMG2900 & HTMG3900) which is a requirement for graduation. Both Internship I and II serve as pre-requisites for HTMG4900. That is, the enrolment in HTMG4900 is subject to the successful completion of the two summer internships requirements.   Before the internship, all students are required to participate in the pre-internship workshops prior to their first summer break. Pre-internship training will be provided for students to acquire the business etiquette, resume writing, interview skills and interpersonal skills required for succeeding in a workplace.
required_readings: • Guiding your internship: a hospitality/tourism manual, Mary Walk, Nancy Pike, Prentice-Hall, 1989 • Hospitality Management Internship: A Student Workbook, Kimberly J. Harris, Florida State University, 2005.
recommended_readings: Nil

title: Advanced Real Estate Investments
description: This course is a continuation course of HTMG3523 Introduction to Real Estate Investment. In this course, a review of the financial modelling techniques and how to apply them to analyze development projects will be covered. A particular topic will focus on the financial analysis of real estate development (the market that links the space market and the asset market in a dynamic real estate system). Developing real estate is a high risky investment, to determine a project’s viability; feasibility study must be carried out, which include a comprehensive analysis of the property development process from initial financial evaluation through construction to final sale. Students will use the acquired financial modelling skills and through the application of market research and intelligence to develop credible feasibility reports.
outcome: On successfully completing this course, students should be able to: • Demonstrate how to analyze and apply financial methods to forecast cash flows for property developments; • Demonstrate skills of assessing risk and return in development projects and to evaluate project viability; • Understand the economics of property developments, the process, the stages in the development process and the key actors involved; • Demonstrate capability to perform an effective pitch of commercial real estate transaction (application to concrete situation). • Critically analyze and evaluate development opportunities in real world business and discuss real world phenomena; • Understand and apply modern portfolio theory, the capital asset pricing model and portfolio performance measurement and real estate market efficiency to real estate investment analysis and management • Develop creative thinking, self-managed ability, team work spirit, analytical and communicative skills through class discussions and project presentations.
syllabus: • Development feasibilities; • Development projects cash-flow models; • Buy-to-sale analysis; • Residual Valuation;  • Modern Portfolio Theory • Capital Asset Pricing Model
required_readings: Commercial Real Estate Analysis and Investments, by Geltner, Miller, Clayton and Eichholtz, Cengage Learning; 2nd edition, 2007  Finance for Real Estate Development, by Long, Charles, Urban Land Institute, 2011
recommended_readings: Property Valuation and Analysis, by R.T.M Whipple, Reginald Thomas Milner:2nd edition, 2006

title: Services Marketing
description: This course discusses marketing strategies of service firms, new marketing approach, and reformulation of traditional marketing principles. It will also address issues related to international marketing with emphasis on the hospitality and tourism industry.

title: Distinguished Speaker Series VII
description: This is the 7th course in the series. To keep abreast of the development that affects current managerial practices, hospitality, tourism and service-related executives are invited as speakers to address the opportunities and challenges facing their fields. Students learn from the industry leaders their visions, experiences and views regarding successful management styles, and critical industry-related issues. In addition, students are required to research and analyze the background of the executives and their companies regarding the company history, mission and philosophy, culture and strategy. They will gain valuable insights from best practices in the industry and at the same time, to reflect on career aspirations and identify their own career paths.
outcome: Business concepts and functions  - Successful industry leaders to share their visions, experiences, and views regarding the recent development of management practices and critical issues in the hospitality industry - Understand the hospitality and tourism industry, key trends and issues impacting the industry, and management practices used  Analytical skills  - Improve critical thinking and writing skills through reflection papers about the guest speakers  Professional Skills  - Successful industry leaders to share their visions, experiences, and views regarding the recent development of management practices and critical issues in the hospitality industry  Attitude/Values - Successful industry leaders to share their own career paths and offer career aspirations to the students
syllabus: The field of hospitality and tourism management is a fast-paced, ever changing industry that requires tireless dedication, strong commitment, positive attitude and keen knowledge. Those who make it to top positions of leadership possess these abilities and traits, among others.   The Distinguished Speaker Series provides a unique opportunity for successful industry leaders to share their visions, experiences, and views regarding the recent development of management practices and critical issues in the hospitality industry. The speakers also share their own career paths and offer career aspirations to the students in the program. Upon completion of this course, students should have a better understanding of the hospitality and tourism industry, key trends and issues impacting the industry, and management practices used. Students will also improve their critical thinking and writing skills through reflection papers they will write about the guest speakers.
required_readings: Nil
recommended_readings: Subject to the recommendations by invited speakers.

title: Real Estate Valuation
description: This course deals with the valuation of property that is typically purchased as an income-producing investment. It covers both the theory and techniques involved in estimating the valuation of the property. The topics include the highest and best use analysis, cost approach,market approach, income approach, Hedonic Pricing Model, leased fee and leasehold valuation, and valuation of proposed projects. Special emphasis will be placed on hospitality property valuation.
outcome: 1)A good understanding of the finance principles applied to real estate valuation  2)A good understanding of real estate valuation in hospitality real estate finance context 3)A good understanding of the application of hospitality real estate valuation in Hong Kong 4)A good understanding of how to apply learned real estate valuation concepts in the hospitality real estate markets in Hong Kong

title: Convention and Meeting Planning Management
description: This is the study of the meetings and convention industry. The focus of this course will be on the components and processes involved in developing and conducting meetings and conventions.

title: Entrepreneurship in the Hospitality and Real Estate Industry
description: Entrepreneurial opportunities exist in all industries. The hospitality industry provides abundant opportunities for entrepreneurs and small businesses. Even in the traditionally capital-intensive industries such as the real estate industry, new business models have emerged in a variety of formats to capture the opportunities brought by advanced information technologies, changing consumer lifestyles, and new service initiatives. This course is about entrepreneurship and new business ideas. Students will learn about the role of entrepreneurship in these service industries and the characteristics of entrepreneurs and small businesses. The course covers the fundamentals of creating and managing a start-up company, including the skills in generating a viable business model, designing products/services, marketing, branding, financing, and implementing chosen strategies (e.g. designing an organizational structure and managing human resources). The skills learned in this course will better prepare the students for capturing the emerging entrepreneurial opportunities in their future careers.

title: Data Leveraging and Modelling for the Hospitality Industry
requirements: Prerequisite: DSME2050 for HMG students, at least one information systems or computer science course for Business or Engineering Majors.
description: The focus will be on practical applications to the hospitality industry. This is a course designed to provide students with the fundamental tools, skills, and concepts to effectively leverage data for the purpose of creating effective information to support their decision making. Tools used will centre on relational database and electronic spreadsheet software. Skills will include basic data base design, relational algebra, and basic SQL with the database application, and model design and feature use with the spreadsheet. Emphasis will also be placed on how to transfer relevant data from a database environment to a spreadsheet tool so the data can be integrated in a simple decision support system. Concepts will include proper tool use for intended aims (e.g.,database management tools for data management and spreadsheet tools for data manipulation), data integrity through database design and query, and decision support concepts through modular design and effective application of "what if" modelling.

title: Human Resources Strategy in Hospitality
description: The goal of this course is to explore the linkages among (internal and external) environmental factors, human resource (HR) strategy, HR systems, and organizational effectiveness. The focus of this course is on the organizational level of analysis. Thus our attention is on HR strategy and systems rather than individual human resource management (HRM) practices. Strategy is typically viewed as a capstone field where the knowledge gained in many different disciplines - such as accounting, marketing, finance, etc. - is integrated with an eye towards their overall impact on organizational effectiveness. We will be using this approach in this course. Our ultimate objective will be to learn how alignment among (internal and external) environmental factors, HR strategy, and HR systems - i.e. systems comprised of HRM practices such as staffing, training, employee development, compensation, empowerment, performance evaluation and work design, etc. - can be aligned to enhance the capacity of hospitality organizations to achieve their strategic goals and objectives. The importance of alignment is magnified in the hospitality industries because within these industries people have the greatest opportunity to impact organizational outcomes.

title: Global Asset Allocation on Real Estate Securities
description: This is an one-semester course that provides conceptual and theoretical foundation for global asset allocation with the applications to real estate securities and hospitality industry. Using a blend of academic and practitioner-oriented readings, case studies, projects, and group analytical sessions, students will be introduced to both the conventional wisdom and state-of-art methods used in managing a global real estate securities portfolio, especially for the hospitality industry. It is assumed that students have completed (or are concurrently enrolled in) the relevant prerequisite courses in finance, accounting and statistics.
outcome: - Discuss key top-down considerations of asset allocation for individual and institutional investors - Describe the characteristics and markets for various types of real estate securities - Apply bottom-up techniques to determine the value of real estate securities - If possible, learn to use Bloomberg to collect and analyze financial data  - Evaluate evidence and implications of the efficient market hypothesis on real estate security markets  - Apply international CAPM and multifactor models in global asset allocation analysis - Discuss basic strategic and tactical strategies of real estate securities portfolio management  - Discuss basic features of real estate derivatives and their applications in investment management
syllabus: - Discuss key top-down considerations of asset allocation for individual and institutional investors - Describe the characteristics and markets for various types of real estate securities - Apply bottom-up techniques to determine the value of real estate securities - If possible, learn to use Bloomberg to collect and analyze financial data  - Evaluate evidence and implications of the efficient market hypothesis on real estate security markets  - Apply international CAPM and multifactor models in global asset allocation analysis - Discuss basic strategic and tactical strategies of real estate securities portfolio management  - Discuss basic features of real estate derivatives and their applications in investment management

title: Strategic Brand Management for Hospitality Business
description: One of the most effective tools to differentiate services from competitors is an organization’s brand identity. Strong brands will transcend industries and provide an organization with one of its most valuable assets. Hence, strategic brand management is one of the hot marketing topics in recent years. Branding has also become an essential component of marketing strategy in the hotel industry. To blend the theory and practice of brand management, this course provides students with the knowledge and skills needed to develop, manage and promote the core values of an organization’s brand in competitive markets. Particular emphasis will be placed on the design of marketing programs to build brand equity in the services and hospitality industry. Students are expected to have developed a basic understanding of brand management concepts and principles through readings, case studies, and a course project for practical application and experiential learning.
outcome: On completion of this course, students will be able to: 1. explain the concepts and theories of brand management, including brand image, brand positioning, brand equity, brand extensions, brand relationships, and consumer responses to brand strategies, etc.;  2. have a good knowledge on the strategies that business organizations use to develop, manage and promote the core values of their brands in competitive markets; 3. apply the brand management concepts to analyse, understand and interpret brand management strategies used by the existing services and hospitality firms; 4. work in a team to apply necessary concepts to design a new marketing program to build brand equity for hospitality brands.  Measurement of Learning Outcomes: 1. Problem based continuous assessment requires students individually or in groups to explain the applications of concepts, theories and principles of brand management in real life problem situations. 2. Mini case studies require students to analyse and interpret the brand management strategies for successful hospitality brands. Students in groups are expected to discuss the applications of relevant concepts and practices in real business case scenario.  3. Class assignments are used to test students’ understanding of specific concepts and practices underlined by trade and academic articles. 4. Final examination specifically requires students to apply knowledge and past learning in addressing the case and examination questions.
syllabus: This course consists of presentation of text materials, discussion of current events in brand management, and application of the concepts and theories to real world situations through case analyses, and critique of recently published academic articles. Tactics and techniques for brand management cases will be discussed during class and students will learn how to apply concepts to solve brand building problems from an organization viewpoint. Particular emphasis will be placed on the design of marketing programs to build brand equity for hospitality brands. Students are expected to apply appropriate brand management concepts and strategies to design a marketing program for brand building. A course project will be emphasized for practical application and experiential learning.   Indicative content including: 1. Identifying and Establishing Brand Positioning and Values: concepts of customer-based brand equity and brand positioning.  2. Planning and Implementing Brand Marketing Programs: choosing brand elements to build brand equity, designing marketing programs to build brand equity, and integrating marketing communications to build brand equity. 3. Measuring and Interpreting Brand Performance: developing brand equity measurement, measuring sources of brand equity, and measuring outcomes of brand equity. 4. Growing and Sustaining Brand Equity: designing and implementing branding strategies, introducing and naming new products and brand extensions.  5. Managing Brands over Time: maintaining brand consistency and protecting sources of brand equity.

title: Consultation Practicum in Hospitality and Real Estate
requirements: Prerequisite: Year 3 or above students having completed HTMG2900 or HTMG3900.
description: This course provides a platform for students to develop and enhance their knowledge and skills necessary for solving real business problems in the hospitality and real estate industries. Students will be presented with an actual business issue provided by industry partners, "the client", and will need to conduct research, define potential alternatives, and make a feasible final recommendation to address the issue. Solving business problems on an ongoing basis is a challenge a manager will face and this course will simulate how issues are defined and addressed to provide a valuable experiential learning opportunity.Students will work in teams to study a business problem or opportunity defined by the client and provide recommendations in a consultative style. The project task will change semester to semester and by group based on the client’s requirements. There will be scheduled meetings between the groups and the appointed faculty advisor(s) over the project process. and provide students with suggested resources. The faculty advisor(s)’ role is to suggest information/research resources and provide advice / ask questions, but not to give answers or direction on what to do. Students will work mostly with their own team and will need to identify a team leader who will be the point of contact with the client.Project task(s), guidelines, and background material will be provided at the beginning of the semester. A number of class workshops will be arranged to help students learn skills required in developing a solution and working with the industry partners. Groups will need to present their solutions/recommendations to the client at the end of the semester and course work will be evaluated by the client and the faculty advisor(s) together.

title: Innovative Issues in Hospitality and Real Estate Industry
description: Innovation has recently emerged as one of the hottest business issues in the world. Some industries are even experiencing the motto “innovate or perish”. Nowadays innovation is not restrictedly used in technology industries, but commonly adopted in servicing fields such as finance and marketing. Hospitality business is inevitably requiring innovation almost every hour as guests are so demanding these days – from on-demand AV facilities on planes to social media platforms from hotels. Real estate business, which did not pay much attention to innovation in the past, is now rapidly innovating from new technology. This industry is now embracing the digital technology and the benefits it generates, which include virtual showcasing, artificial intelligence and smart homes.The objective of this course is to provide our students an overview of innovation in hospitality and real estate business. The course adopts an interactive project based learning approach. Students will learn about concepts and features of innovation and apply the concept through working on a business project, from proposal to implementation.

title: Consumer Insight and Marketing Analytics for Hospitality Industry
description: There are three modules in this course. The first module demonstrates how to calculate, interpret and evaluate customer analytics related to CRM such as the size of wallet, the share of wallet and customer lifetime value. The second module introduces several digital marketing analytical tools to monitor and evaluate the performance of hospitality companies in major social media platforms with some hands-on exercises. The third module teaches students how to analyze, visualize and apply survey data to glean customer insights, measure customer satisfaction, and design effective acquisition campaigns and rewards programs.

title: Revitalization of Heritage Buildings
description: In recent years, rapid development and intense tourism growth have posed threats to heritage buildings. Thus, scientific management and innovative revitalization are vital for facilitating the sustainable development of heritage buildings. This course focuses on heritage buildings and sites in relation to their settings and aims to enable students’ understanding of the relationships between heritage buildings and sustainable urban development. It introduces revitalization principles, policies and processes; concepts of property rights and sustainability; heritage tourism marketing strategies; and examples of heritage revitalization in Hong Kong and oversea to students through both classroom teaching and field trips. Students will be taught to adopt innovative technology (e.g. virtual reality technology) in examining the existing heritage buildings and integrate innovative design in developing revitalization strategies.

title: Global Hotel Chain Management
description: The course covers topics such as the challenges and opportunities facing global expansion, strategic development of international hospitality projects and international development process.

title: Airline Management
description: This course will provide insights into the dynamics of airline management, including topics on airline organization, airline marketing and distribution networks, and/or airline catering operation and service management.

title: Theme Park Management
