title: Convention, Exhibition and Event Management
description: This is the study of the meetings and convention industry. The focus of this course will be on the components and processes involved in developing and conducting meetings and conventions.

title: Pre-Opening of a Hotel Property
description: The course will cover relevant issues and challenges relating to pre-opening of a hotel property. Topics include project management, market feasibility, concept and theme development,layout and design, financing, recruitment, training of personnel, and locating of suppliers.

title: Beverage Management
description: Beverage sales comprise a major source of profit for hospitality operations. This course examines the principles and practices of profitable beverage (alcoholic and non-alcoholic) management in the hospitality industry. Topics covered in the course module include wholesaler-operator relations, purchasing and inventory control, beverage preparation and service, and financial accountability and control.

title: Franchising & Multi-Unit Management in the Hospitality Industry
description: This course discusses selected topics on franchising and multi-unit management. Topics may cover the relationship between franchisor and franchisee, advantages and disadvantages of using franchising in the hospitality industry and the structure of and services offered by franchisors in the hospitality industry, etc..

title: Hotel Development
description: This course will examine those factors to consider in determining hotel development includin gentry modes and country specifics, etc.. Decision criteria, ownership structure, financial management and profits, trends in hotel development will also be examined.

title: Cruise Line Management
description: This course seeks to create awareness of the ocean cruise industry as a unique combination of the hospitality, tourism, marketing, and shipping industries. Topics covered include evolution of the modern cruise industry, market segmentation, itinerary and product development,ship design and regulatory issues, and cost and revenue issues.

title: Club Management
description: This course is designed to familiarize students with club management as it compares to hotel management. Topics include club management structure, club membership, types of private clubs, unique features of club operations, food and beverage operations, building and facilities management, and external and governmental influences.

title: Hospitality Properties Mergers and Acquisitions
description: This course will familiarize students with issues and current trends concerning mergers andacquisitions of hospitality properties. Purpose and objectives of mergers and acquisitions activities and their relationships will be addressed. The course will examine the topics from different aspects: business, operating, corporate, legal and regulatory.

title: Hotel Design
description: To hotel developers, of chains, groups, franchises, and independents alike, one of the critical elements that adds up to the success in the world of international hospitality, is design. In the multinational global entity, whenever new hotels open, in order to succeed they will have to meet the high standards of architecture and design that have been established over the recent decades. Topics incude factors influences on design, global trends in hotel design, infrastucture, environmental standards, life safety, brands, design consideration, architectural and interior design style reflecting different cultural concerns, restaurants and food/beverage concepts designed for both guests and non-guests, organization, positioning, competitor's facilities and marketing, facility programming and cost analysis, building plans, maintenance and refurbishment.

title: Development and Management of Hotels and Serviced Apartments
description: This course is designed to provide students with insights on how to develop and manage hotel and serviced apartments. Topics include ownership structure and funding, mergers and acquisitions, the use of management companies or in house management, marketing strategies,market research, site selection, concept development, project management, human resources management, management system and control.

title: Hotel Business Operation in China
description: China is growing to be the world's leading tourist destination in 2020. This course is designedto give an introduction to those students who may consider pursuing their career in the hotelindustry in mainland China. Through this course, students will learn how to equip themselveswith the right attitude and management tools, as well as how to establish their relationship with the local environment. Emphasis will be placed on operating in business environmentin primary cities like Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou. Specifically, the unique features ofstarting and running a successful hotel business operation in China will be addressed. Topics will include political, legal and economic environment in China, ownership and managementof hotels, quality of workforce, the importance of quanxi (關係), objectives of pre-opening activities and their relationship, and the process of running a hotel from the functional areas of management perspective.

title: Spa Management and Facilities
description: Spa facilities become a must-have for five star hotels. The course is designed to familiarize students with the latest trend in spa development and management of spa facilities. Topics covered will include the concept of health tourism, history of spa, types of spa, spa market segments, threats and opportunities facing the spa industry, holistic selection of spa treatments, profiling spa goers, design, investment criteria, management and maintenance of spa facilities, training of spa personnel, and career path in spa industry.

title: Development and Management of Casino Gaming
description: This course aims at familiarizing students with the unique features and structure of casino gaming, hence introducing the particular managerial issues associated with this rapidly expanding business in the global and regional markets. The Macao's casino industry is oneof the world's famous casino jurisdictions and it has close relationship with Hong Kong. Thus, this course will scrutinize the situation, changing structure and performance of Macao's casino industry. Topics include impacts of Macao's casino industry on the Hong Kong economy, especially tourism, the progress and prospects of casino gaming in East Asia, and the associated business opportunities and challenges faced by various jurisdictions.

title: Sustainable Tourism
description: The need to provide balanced development addressing social, economic and environmental factors has been widely recognized, and the pursuit of sustainable development placed high on the International Agenda. This has resulted in the development of policy frameworks at National and Local government levels, and within key economic sectors. The significant role of the Tourism Industry in this regard was recognized as early as 1996 through the joint publication by the World Travel and Tourism Council, the World Tourism Organization and the Earth Council of "Agenda 21 for the Travel and Tourism Industry". This document set out a framework for the tourism industry to address key sustainability challenges and contribute towards broader sustainable development strategies. This course is intended to provide students the ability to understand the key principles and trends, strategies for successful interventions within the tourism industry, and the tools available to assist in decision making and implementation of such sustainable tourism strategies. These range from implementation of management systems and sustainable technologies, through training of staff and customer servicing, to new tourism products such as eco, cultural, and adventure tourism. The changing market dynamics will be discussed as well as the need to integrate sustainable development into all modes of travel and tourism.

title: Entrepreneurship in Hospitality and Real Estate
description: Most business courses focus on how to operate and further develop an established entity. This course introduces a framework for understanding and learning the key success factors during the startup phase of a venture, the first ten yards of a sprint race. The framework covers: personal operating system (of the founder), product/services, management tools, the garage team, and the culture/environment. In particular, we will zoom into the management tools and product characteristics of successful ventures in hospitality and real estate related cases. The objectives are to build an initial awareness of different skills required and how to build up these skills as well as to develop an appreciation of the importance of entrepreneurial spirit in the hospitality and real estate industries. We will use plenty of local and overseas entrepreneurial examples in related industries and many short team presentations and exercises.

title: Destination Marketing
description: The only thing stays constant in today's global environment is "change". With the economic turmoil of the recent past, most countries in Asia Pacific region are recognizing the importance of tourism as one of the major contributor for the economy and the provider for multiple levels of employment opportunities. The challenges and threats to Asian tourism have never been greater, as new opportunities arise and new threats mount at an ever increasing rate. In this highly volatile and competitive environment, the tourism destinations that have a good comprehension of the concept of Strategic Destination Marketing and the discipline of systematic implementation and evaluation of its initiatives will be the ultimate winners. The course provides students with the opportunity to learn up-to-date principles and trends of Destination Marketing. Emphasis is on the understanding of the applications of latest skills and knowledge to specific places faced with different challenges and opportunities. This is enhanced through the interactive sharing of real life examples, demonstrated by some major key players in the market during the course sessions.

title: Market and Financial Feasibility Studies for Hospitality and Real Estate
description: Before a hotel is developed, a feasibility study is critical to determine the success of the project. The next aspect in a successful hotel development is securing the most appropriate brand for the hotel. Topics in this course will include a step-by-step approach to conducting a feasibility study, market data analysis that incorporates critical decision points, supply and demand analysis, financial projections and investment analysis, and techniques for facilities recommendations. Furthermore the process of securing a hotel management company for a property developer and the key commercial terms in hotel management contract negotiations will be discussed.

title: Event Planning and Management
description: The Meeting, Exhibition, Incentive, Convention and Exhibition (MICE) sector is important to the Hong Kong economy. It has gathered momentum in recent years. Through additional funding from the Hong Kong Government, the Hong Kong Tourism Board steps up MICE promotion by launching the “Meetings and Exhibitions Hong Kong” (MEHK) office. This course will expose students to the MICE industry from an event management perspective. The topics covered will include the importance of the MICE market to a hotel, facilities and resources needed to support MICE business, effective strategies and selling approaches to win MICE business, and how to coordinate among different departments and manage event business in the hotel.

title: Developing a Competitive and Sustainable Exhibition Industry in Hong Kong
description: Exhibition industry is indispensable to the Hong Kong economy. From a service provider's perspective, this course will provide students with an overview of the Hong Kong exhibition industry at present as well as the historical development of this industry back from old days. Students will also be able to learn the importance of a healthy exhibition industry and the ways to nurture a sustainable development of the Hong Kong exhibition industry. Overseas experiences would be showcased for students to understand the different challenges and opportunities ahead.

title: Talent Management in the Hospitality Industry
description: The course is aimed at introducing the concepts of talent management in hospitality industry. Topics may include talent management in overall HR planning; talent identification and development; and the related current practices in hospitality industry.

title: Attraction Marketing
description: Travel and tourism industry has become one of the major economic pillars in Hong Kong. In recent years, there are significant capital projects such as HK-Macau-Zhuhai Bridge, High Speed Railway and Kai Tak Cruise Terminal. It is anticipated these infrastructures will bring more visitors to Hong Kong. To meet the demand of the increasing number of visitors, there is a need to increase new attractions and improve existing attractions. Ocean Park Hong Kong and Hong Kong Disneyland are embarking on numerous expansion projects in order to attract new visitors as well as repeat visitors. In the meantime, it becomes indispensable to depend on attraction marketing to enhance product awareness and visitor engagement in promoting Hong Kong as one of the key tourism destinations in the world. This course will deliberate on the concept of attraction marketing and explore best practices including B2B, B2C, branding, event management, and social media marketing.

title: High-speed Rail and Tourism
description: The successful launch of the Shinkansen passenger train service between Tokyo and Osaka in 1964 unveiled a new era of railway travel in the last 50 years. The impressive pace of development of high-speed rail networks worldwide has greatly enhanced the accessibility and connectivity of major cities, as well as significantly improved the convenience, safety and comfort level of long distance travel. High-speed rail has reshaped the travel market, promoted tourist destinations and re-defined the competition between air and rail. With its high capacity, greater energy efficiency and relatively lower carbon footprint, high-speed rail is often described as the “transport mode of the future” due to its contribution to the long-term sustainability of tourism.The objective of the course is to provide an overview of high-speed rail development in major tourist generating and destination regions in the world, highlighting the key design features and services, tourism-transport relationships, the impact on tourism and destination growth, market competition and major policy considerations addressed by government bodies at the planning and implementation stages. It aims at giving students a new perspective on the rapid transformation of the patterns of inter-regional and international travel brought about by the advancement in railway technology. The course is designed to enrich the knowledge of students on the importance of high- speed rail within the tourism system and should suit the needs of those who are interested in further developing their career in the hospitality, tourism and transport industries.The 26-km long Hong Kong Section of the Express Rail Link is being constructed to connect Hong Kong with the National High-speed Railway Network. Upon its opening in 2017, Hong Kong’s role as the southern gateway to the Mainland is expected to be further enhanced. This course thus provides a timely update to students on the interplay between high-speed rail and tourism, and the future trends.

title: Brand Management in Hospitality
description: While branding has really only come of age in the last century, the idea of a brand as a mark of origin or trademark has a long history. The word itself derived from Old Norse and means “to burn” – as in literally burning a mark on property to signify ownership. On the most basic level a brand is still about a promise of consistency and a mark of value, but the role of branding is much more complex. Today, there is widespread recognition that brands are more than a logo that stimulates recognition and helps to identify a product or service. Instead we now appreciate that it is the emotional and intangible qualities that underpin the value of a brand. The hospitality sector has been quick to embrace “brand” in this regard recognizing that these qualities offer the greatest means of competitive advantage. Thus, to not only succeed but to thrive in a competitive landscape, hotels and other service brands in the wider hospitality sector, need to stand out by “standing for” something. There are now actual processes in place to achieve this. They require a position upon which to build the brand and its reputation, a brand strategy to tell and manage the brand’s story and a business plan with strong competencies and capabilities that create value. The key objective of this course then is to provide an overview on the role of brand (and its constituent parts) in building and sustaining an organization’s reputation and hence competitive advantage. The modules contain content specific to the hospitality sector in all these respects. Informative and relevant, students can make use of the knowledge gained in the course either in their role as brand ambassadors within the organizations they join or as entrepreneurs establishing their own brand.

title: Introduction to Retail Management
description: The Retail Industry is important in the hospitality industry. Hong Kong is a key touristic destination in the world and is renowned for providing visitors with exciting and exceptional products and shopping experiences. This industry is also important in China because of the huge population base and the country’s growing strategic shift in recognition of the importance of the Service Industries.The Retail Industry is a highly competitive industry and there are special management skills and trainings required in order to lead and succeed in the business. This industry also provides ample opportunities for graduates in their career advancements.The objective of this course is to provide an overview of the Retail Industry including its growing importance, especially in China and the Asia Pacific Region. There will be highlights in special and unique strategic and operational management skills required for this industry. The course will also explore the different types of retailing including mass retailing, mega retailing, and luxury retailing. There will also be coverage on career opportunities and advancements for students.

title: Selected Topics on Global Business Challenges
description: This course is designed to increase students’ understanding of the complex and evolving challenges that organizations face when managing their businesses in the global context. The course aims for students to develop a global perspective through theme-based lectures, case studies, field trips, manager interviews, and/or projects assigned by real business organizations, particularly those with global operations/investments in the hospitality, tourism, real estate, and other service industries. Students are expected to improve analytical, problem-solving, teamwork, and communication skills by forming groups to research economic, political, technological, and sociocultural issues/trends in the global business environment, analyze strategies and management practices of specific global companies, propose relevant strategic suggestions, and obtain feedback from companies. The practical, context-specific nature of this course will help students better understand how global business opportunities and challenges influence company strategies and operational practices, and how to manage international businesses to achieve strategic, ethical, and sustainability objectives.

title: Commercial Real Estate Investment Analysis
requirements: Pre-requisite(s):;1. HTMG students: HTMG3030 or HTMG4060 or HTMG4100;2. Non-HTMG students: FINA2010 or FINA3080
description: This course offers in-depth training in analytical tools used by real estate investment analysts. Students will learn the strategies and principles of investments, pro forma analysis, risk/return analysis, valuation methods, commercial leases, capital structure and application of decision-making tools. Through global case studies, students will learn the practical knowledge and skills in commercial real estate investment analysis. In addition, students will have the opportunities to integrate their knowledge and skills into case analysis and solving real business problems.

title: Specialty Tourism
description: International tourism has become easier, more affordable, and more personalized. The shift from mass tourism towards a more authentic experience is felt across the tourism horizon, not only in choosing where to go, but also how to travel and what products and services to consume. Specialty tourism emerges to provide customized tourism activities catering to the specific interests of groups and individuals. This course introduces theoretical concepts related to specialty tourism and real-world cases different destinations. This course is designed to keep abreast with the changing tourism landscape and will focus on one type of specialty tourism each time the course is offered. Possible themes include, but not limited to medical tourism, educational tourism, culinary tourism, shopping tourism, cultural tourism, and ecotourism. This course is opened to all CUHK undergraduate students. Students enrolled in this course shall commit to completing a series of tasks designed by the course instructor, including written reports, group projects and an overseas or local study tour, etc. Given the interdisciplinary nature of tourism research, the course address issues related to specialty tourism by combines perspectives from business, marketing, social psychology, consumer behavior, cultural and human geography, environmental sustainability, anthropology and social sciences.

title: Innovation for Hospitality and Real Estate
description: Hospitality and Real Estate (HRE) are dynamic industries that need to constantly change to anticipate the evolving needs of guests, innovation therefore become an inseparable element that must be included in a business process to ensure the quality guest service delivery capability and the competitiveness of the industry. Even though our lives have changed in many ways with the fast development of technology and the evolved Industry 4.0. Innovation is not limited to tangible digital products like smart machine, robotic equipment or greener building, it also includes intangible management process, design or concepts that facilitate efficient use of human capital, marketing effectiveness and financial viability. The objective of this course is to leverage industry expertise to facilitate discussion of tangible innovative products or intangible innovative process and system which are applicable to the Hospitality and Real Estate sectors, and assist students identify, evaluate and generate new business opportunities for HRE.
outcome: Upon completing this course, students should be able to Discuss the relationship of innovation and technology Understand how technology has disrupted the HRE industry Understand main characteristics of an innovation and identify its relevancy to the HRE Apply the learnt innovation concepts to a specific function/sector within the HRE industry Identify, evaluate and generate new business opportunities for HRE

title: Essentials for Hospitality and Real Estate Projects
description: The use of (tactical) project management to deliver projects has been increasing in organizations.A project can be defined as a temporary endeavor undertaken to create a unique product, service, or result. Projects are particularly important for real estate and hospitality organizations, as a company’s strategic vision is operationalized through project management, with the transfer of projects to operations. The ability successfully apply knowledge, skills, tools and techniques to project activities has become an important management competency in the real estate and hospitality industries.The objective of this course is to equip students with basic understanding of:- project management concepts, including the project life cycle and the series of phases the project passes through from its start to its completion, and interdependencies.- project management process groups (initiating, planning, executing, closing and monitoring & controlling). - project management knowledge areas (integration, scope, schedule, cost, quality, resource, communications, risk, procurement, stakeholder).In addition to discussing phases in a project, the students will be equipped with a beginner skills, and tool and techniques to understand typical hospitality project environments (new-build hotel, transition, renovation, product extension / upgrade, service upgrade, IT hard- and software implementation) and support general management and the project team in basic planning and executing of relevant project activities.Finally, the course will explore how Enterprise Environmental Factors (EEFs) influence, constrain, or direct the project.- Internal to the organization: e.g. culture, structure, and governance; geographic distribution of facilities and resources, infrastructure, resource availability, employee capability, etc.- External to the organization: e.g. marketplace conditions, social and cultural influences and issues; legal restrictions, government or industry standards, physical environmental elements, etc. Experiential learning activities such as real-world group projects from the real estate/hospitality fields, active case discussions, and business examples will be offered along with lectures for the purpose of enhancing students’ conceptual understanding and practical skills.
outcome: Upon completing this course, students should be able to understand a project life cycle and phases. understand the project management process groups. understand the project management knowledge areas. identify interdependencies. understand basic scope, schedule, cost and quality tools and techniques. understand key performance metrics for project success. describe how to manage stakeholder interests and relationships in each phase of the project life cycle. understand how Enterprise Environmental Factors facilitate (or hinder) successful project management. support effective project management teams.
syllabus: To be provided by course teacher during class.
required_readings: Nil
recommended_readings: Noordzij, G. (2014). Project Management of New Hotel Opening Processes: Exploring better ways to manage new hotel openings

title: Facilities Development and Management for Hospitality and Real Estate
description: This course introduces the concepts, principles and process of facilities development and management from a hospitality facilities and real estate life cycle perspective, including inception and refinement of the development idea, the public roles of development approvals, the feasibility study, development planning, architectural design, construction and management. Furthermore, strategic and operational facilities management will be taught in the context of technology, cost, legal/contract, environment and performance management. Cases from both hospitality industry (e.g. hotels, museums, theme parks, transportation facilities) and real estate industry (e.g. office buildings, shopping malls, corporate real estate assets) will be discussed in the course.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: • Understand the concepts, principles and process of hospitality facilities/real estate development • Adopt data from market research to develop and evaluate feasibility study report and development proposal • Understand the major factors that affect hospitality facilities/real estate development and management; and • Analyze and evaluate the hospitality facilities/real estate approaches and process
syllabus: This course introduces the concepts, principles and process of facilities development and management from a hospitality facilities and real estate life cycle perspective, including inception and refinement of the development idea, the public roles of development approvals, the feasibility study, development planning, architectural design, construction and management. Furthermore, strategic and operational facilities management will be taught in the context of technology, cost, legal/contract, environment and performance management. Cases from both hospitality industry (e.g. hotels, museums, theme parks, transportation facilities) and real estate industry (e.g. office buildings, shopping malls, corporate real estate assets) will be discussed in the course. The following topics to will be be covered: • Introduction of facilities development and management  • Life cycle of facilities / properties development  • Planning of facilities  • Facilities management  • Corporate real estate and facilities management

title: Strategic Negotiation for Hospitality and Real Estate Industry
description: This course introduces current research and thought on leadership and negotiation. It provides practice opportunities for course participants to apply the concepts and skills in simulations of actual negotiations. Strategic lessons are learned through negotiation exercises and analysis of HRE cases. The objective is to enable course participants to appreciate the art and science of negotiation, to understand how to resolve conflicts, apply appropriate negotiation approaches for specific hospitality or real estate environment, practice negotiation skills at the bargaining table and derive the most out of negotiation process.

title: Hospitality Strategic Management
description: This course focuses on analysis, planning, change, and implementation issues associated with strategic management. It explores business missions, action plans, and evaluations of a hospitality organization. The emphases are on the value of analysing environments and formulating strategies linked to environmental conditions, and defending against organization weaknesses. Students learn how to engage in high-quality planning by examining situations from the perspectives of the customer, the employee, and management. Cases involving hospitality industry organizations are analysed extensively.
outcome: 1) Business Concepts and Functions  First, students are expected to understand three major theoretical perspectives on strategy formulation and implementation: a) the rational model that focuses on SWOT analysis, industry five-force analysis, and generic competitive strategies, b) the resource-based view of competitive advantage, and c) the stakeholder relationship perspective. Students will learn how to apply these theories to describe and prescribe strategies at both business- and corporate-levels. Second, students need to understand strategic management as a process and learn about the various approaches companies use to expand / diversify their businesses. Finally, students are expected to understand the notion of “fit” (external fit and internal fit) and its importance in strategy formulation and implementation (particularly in the area of designing organizational structures and control systems).   2) Analytical Skills Business cases, video clips, and simulation exercises are used in this course for the purpose of training students’ analytical skills. Students are expected to apply different theoretical concepts and approaches to solve “real-world” problems. These exercises are also designed to help students understand that there are no “right” or “wrong” answers in strategy making. They need to deal with uncertainty, understand boundary conditions, and develop reasonable, realistic solutions.   3) Attitude / Values  The notion of ethical decision making is incorporated in every topic of this course. Students are required to learn not only the various ethical principles but also their implications in specific decision contexts. They will learn how to evaluate strategic proposals / solutions from different stakeholders’ perspectives and how to balance different interests / resolve conflicts. One significant element of this course is to encourage students to think beyond profits and take into account business ethics and social responsibilities in every strategic decision.
syllabus: Course Objectives At the conclusion of this course, you are expected to:  1. understand the three major perspectives on strategic management (traditional, resource-based view, and stakeholder management approach) and their applications in hospitality businesses;   2. be able to identify critical elements of a hospitality organization’s external environment and its internal resource base;   3. understand generic business and corporate strategies and how to choose appropriate strategy(ies) that meet environmental requirements and match organizational resources / capabilities;   4. know how to handle critical issues hospitality organizations may encounter in the process of implementing a chosen strategy; and  5. understand how entrepreneurship / innovation and the globalization trends affect hospitality firms’ survival and growth opportunities.

title: Fieldwork and Internship: Theory Construction for the Hospitality and Real Estate Industry
requirements: Prerequisite: HTMG1010 and successful completion of the Summer Internship I and II.
description: The objectives of this course are: (1) to ensure that students are acquainted with actual hospitality and real estate working conditions, (2) to supplement theoretical and academic subject matter with practical experience, (3) to guide students in selecting permanent employment upon graduation, and (4) to nurture an academic mind and enable students to see the intimate relationship between theory and practice. There are two parts to this course: the internship where the students will engage in practicum experience in the hospitality and real estate industry, preferably during the summers before their graduation; the senior portfolio where the students will identify relevant industry issues and provide recommendations. These recommendations are grounded in literature and supported by empirical evidence. Students are also expected to conduct a project in their respective concentration areas.
outcome: 1. Nurture an academic mind to learn from literature independently and make use of concepts to guide evidence based management. 2. Master tools to make concepts operational and tools to collect evidence to substantiate evidence based management.
syllabus: The mission of this course is to show you the intimate relationship between theory and practice, and nurture within you a passion in knowledge pursuit in your daily work. The success of SHTM education hinges on our ability to connect theory to practice. (Incidentally, this is also the education philosophy at Cornell. For many years, according to Dean Michael Johnson, this has been the key to set Cornell Hotel School apart from practically all other hotel schools.) This is a course to enable you to develop a framework to connect theory to practice. There are two specific course objectives: The first objective is to show you how an academic mind shapes an executive mind. We all want to become successful executives. A successful executive is someone who has an executive mind. An executive mind makes effective and efficient decisions. In the meantime, we come to study at a leading university because we want to master the best way to learn how to learn. The best learner is someone who has an academic mind. An academic mind has a firm grasp of literature and knows how to learn from current and historic great minds from different disciplines. When we have an academic mind that can guide our executive mind, we can benefit from literature and make well informed effective and efficient decisions. In this course, we introduce to you a way to see theories through daily actions and to see the relationship between theory and practice. Whenever a practice is highly significant, it pays to go to the root of the practice and make sure that there is a sound theory behind. In the meantime, in implementation, a sound practice will ensure that there is a thorough understanding of the sound theory behind. Theory and practice are two sides of the same coin. In the past two years, you have spent considerable amount of time to gain practical exposure in the hospitality or real estate industries. They include site visits, distinguished speaker series, courses in Executive-in-Residence program, and most important of all, summer internships. All these are precious experiences. When you have an academic mind to distil your experience and link it to a theoretical framework, you will become much more powerful to make good use of your experience to accelerate learning. Experience without learning is hardship. Experience with learning generates personal satisfaction and growth. Learning hinges on whether one has an academic mind, the way to develop the ability to learn how to learn. The ideal of education at SHTM is to enable us to see the implication of a theory to improving practices and also to see a theory behind proven best practices. It is only possible when we have an academic mind.  The second objective is to show you how to nurture an academic mind, the way to develop your ability to learn how to learn. We enable you to appreciate the beauty of the process to develop a body of scientific knowledge in business and social science in the context of the hospitality and real estate industries. This will give you an orientation to appreciate the contribution to literature from various business and social science disciplines, the challenge of problems in the hospitality and real estate industries, the nature of empirical evidence, the importance of journals, books, magazines and libraries, and the meaning of academic work. A university graduate is someone with an academic mind, someone who can make a good connection and grow together with the living and past giants from all walks of life. Those with an academic mind who decide to practise in the industries will be able to make executive decisions with a deep meaning. Those with an academic mind who have a passion in knowledge pursuit may later decide to go for an academic career and contribute directly to the body of scientific knowledge.  Theory construction is the foundation of academic disciplines. This conduct of inquiry prevails across a wide spectrum of courses in the whole curriculum. Thus, when you have established yourself in this course, you will also strengthen your capability of academic pursuit in many other courses. Some students may wonder why we do not teach this course earlier. A straight forward answer is if students do not have enough background (subject matter and work experience), they do not have the ability to learn in this course. Thus, there is no way to teach this course earlier. Some students may also wonder since they are already senior students when they take this course, there will be no chance for them to make use of the knowledge in this course to strengthen their capability of academic pursuit in other courses. A straight forward answer is academic pursuit is life long. One will revisit different course materials from time to time even long after graduation. After all, the main purpose of university education is to assist students to become independent learners during and after their university study. As a matter of fact, their independent learning ability will dictate their chance of success as a leader in the society. While students nurture the independent learning ability mainly during their university study (normally lasting for three to four years), most of their independent learning actually happens after graduation (normally lasting for 50 to 60 years).

title: Real Estate Finance
requirements: For students in MSc in Management of Real Estate and Hospitality Assets
description: The turmoil in real estate market, which is one of the largest and most important components of the financial system, could bring a negative impact to the world financial markets. The participants in the real estate market should understand how to evaluate the risk and return concerning various ways of financing. This course exposes students to concepts, theories and industry practice in real estate finance. Topics related to real estate finance, including legal foundation of real estate finance, mortgage loans, secondary mortgage market, mortgage-backed securities and financial leverage, will be discussed. Different alternative real estate financing vehicles, such as real estate investment trust (REIT), will also be examined. The primary goal of this course is to help students develop the conceptual knowledge and analytical skills of real estate finance, including those related to the institutions and instruments used to finance residential and commercial real estate. After taking this course, the students are expected to understand the importance of different financing methods and be able to make informed real estate finance decisions.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students should be able to: • Understand the fundamental principles of real estate finance, the key concepts and the important relations underlying commercial real estate • Demonstrate knowledge and understanding on how the mortgage loans are structured in real estate financing • Apply different mortgage loans to commercial real estate projects • Critically analyze the use of different financing methods in real estate projects
syllabus: • Legal foundations of real estate finance • Mathematics of real estate finance • Mortgage Instruments I: Fixed Rate Mortgages  • Mortgage Instruments II: Adjustable Rate Mortgages and others • Mortgage Prepayment and Default • Secondary mortgage market • Mortgage-backed securities • Cash Flow, NOI and Commercial Real Estate Finance • Alternative financing vehicles

Mason, Ohio: Cengage Learning. • Terrence, M.C. and Sirmans, G.S. (2010) Real Estate Finance: Theory and Practice, 6th edition. Mason, Ohio: Cengage Learning. • Journals: (Asian) Wall Street Journal, Economist, Business Week, Far Eastern Economic Review, Hong Kong Economic Journal.

title: Property Development and Investment
requirements: For students in MSc in Management of Real Estate and Hospitality Assets
description: This course provides fundamental knowledge of and analytical tools for property development and investment. The course links space market and asset market in a dynamic real estate system and focuses on topics such as principles of commercial property investment analysis, cash flow analysis, real estate project investment analysis, etc. We will also discuss issues related to development project investment analysis, including definition and measurement of risk and return, valuation of land and multiple-phase development projects based on real option theory, financial modelling for real estate investment, feasibility studies, financial evaluation procedure based on net present value (NPV), and estimation of operational leverage and opportunity capital cost (OCC) for development investment. Various global case studies will be used to guide theoretical learning and class discussion.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students should be able to: - Understand the foundations of real estate investment concepts and theories and apply the knowledge in different real estate settings in a global context; - Understand the nature of return and risk quantification and characteristics of property development and investment appraisals; - Understand the theory and mechanics of financial feasibility studies in the property development process and know the strengths and weaknesses of development appraisals; - Demonstrate capability to construct financial models using Microsoft Excel and Argus to do risk/return analysis and determine property value and income before they enter the workplace; - Apply valuation techniques to assess the value of different asset classes and project feasibility at prevailing market rents, land prices, and construction and financing costs, thus help to make informed investment decisions;  - Develop creative thinking, self-managed ability, leadership skills, team work spirit, analytical and communicative skills and oral presentation skills that are appropriate in a variety of investment scenarios through case studies and group projects; - Understand and apply the knowledge of property investment and development analysis skills to real world practices and deliver excellent services to potential clients; - Identify and address ethical issues in both real estate investment and development processes.
syllabus: • Investment analysis, cash-flows and financial modelling; • Economic analysis of development with real option theory;  • Simple financial feasibility analysis (SFFA);  • NPV-based financial evaluation procedure for commercial and development projects.

title: Services Management
requirements: For students in MSc in Management of Real Estate and Hospitality Assets
description: The trend toward service-dominated economies has been global in scope. Not surprisingly, services are the major driver of economic growth in Asia, where the share of services in the most advanced economies is comparable to that of their U.S. and European counterparts. Given the importance of services in the world economy, it is imperative for students to have basic knowledge of services marketing. This course aims to equip students with the fundamental knowledge and skills of services marketing. Feature topics include the fundamental differences between services and goods, service strategies of managing the service experience, and consumer perception of service quality and service delivery.

title: Hospitality Strategic Human Resources Management
requirements: For students in MSc in Management of Real Estate and Hospitality Assets
description: Strategic human resources management is a central issue in hospitality management as a people business and labor intensive industry. Human resources management is about how to select, motivate and retain service-oriented employees from a human capital perspective. Special challenges in human resource management issues in this context include diverse employee backgrounds and roles, a focus on guest services, long and unsociable working hours. By making such industry-specific concerns the cornerstone of its approach, the course provides the definitive guide to successfully employing people in a hospitality organization. Topics include strategic role of human resources management in achieving company objectives, the challenges in diversity, career planning/development, succession planning, skill sets needed at different stage of career ladder, work-life balance and critical issues affecting human resources practices in hospitality and tourism industries.

title: Chain Development and Management
requirements: For students in MSc in Management of Real Estate and Hospitality Assets
description: The course is designed to introduce students to the organization, administration, concepts and theories in chain management in the hospitality industry as well as the evaluation of existing and challenging practices. The students will learn the growth and development of major hospitality chains and to analyze their strategies and tactics at different levels and markets. Topics include overview of chain operations in the hospitality industry, fundamental theories and principles of chain management, corporate entrepreneurship, competitive strategies of hospitality chains and brands at different stages of corporate life cycle, perspectives of owners, developers and lenders as well as management contract, franchising, joint venture and strategic alliance.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the students should be able to: • Understand the critical theories and principles of the development and management of hospitality firms with multi-units • Examine and analyze different level of strategies that are espoused by hospitality organizations • Understand the unique characteristics of functional areas of management pertaining to chain management  • Analyze and critically assess the co-alignment of internal structure and external environment of chain hospitality organizations  • Develop appropriate strategies and propose effective implementation and evaluation methods for the hospitality organizations
syllabus: • Overview of chain operations in the hospitality industry • Essential theories and principles of chain management • Competitive strategies to match corporate missions and cultures in hospitality firms • Modes of expansion regarding management contract, franchising, joint venture and strategic alliance • Perspectives of owners, developers and lenders • Corporate entrepreneurship and innovative orientation • Characteristics of functional area of management pertaining to chain hospitality firms • Organizational structure to align with competitive strategies

title: Strategy and Competitive Advantage
requirements: For students in MSc in Management of Real Estate and Hospitality Assets
description: The course is designed to offer students with an integrative framework for planning and executing corporate-, business- and function-level strategies that help hospitality and tourism companies achieve sustainable competitive advantage. It introduces a wide variety of contemporary strategic analysis tools. Topics include strategic decisions as formulating competitive strategies, diversification, internal resources / capabilities, external environments assessment, stakeholder relationships, strategic alliances, organizational structure and control mechanisms in hospitality and tourism industries. Critical issues related to ethical decision making and corporate social responsibilities will also be addressed.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the students should be able to: • Be familiar with major perspectives on strategic management and their applications in hospitality businesses;  • Identify critical elements of a hospitality organization's external environment and its internal resource base;  • Understand generic business and corporate strategies and how to choose appropriate strategy(ies) that meet environmental requirements and match organizational resources / capabilities;  • Apply knowledge previously acquired from work experience and the classroom to strategic issues related to hospitality companies; and • Develop and exercise critical thinking, persuasive written and verbal communication skills.
syllabus: • Strategic management process • Major theoretical perspectives on strategic management  • SWOT analysis  • Business-level strategies  - Cost leadership   - Product differentiation • Corporate strategies  - Vertical integration  - Corporate diversification  - Strategic alliances  - Mergers & acquisitions   - International strategies • Implementation of strategies  - Stakeholder relationship management  - Organizational design and control
required_readings: Cathy A. Enz, 2010. Hospitality Strategic Management: Concepts and Cases, 2nd edition. John Wiley & Sons Inc.
recommended_readings: Jay B. Barney & William S. Hesterly, 2012. Strategic Management and Competitive Advantage: Concepts and Cases, 4th edition. Pearson.

title: Travel and Tourism Management
requirements: For students in MSc in Management of Real Estate and Hospitality Assets
description: This course focuses on the management of travel and tourism businesses and the impact of the industry to the society, particularly to the developing nations. Reference will be made to the booming tourism industry in Hong Kong, China and Asia/Pacific. Topics include historical evolution and the changing nature of the industry, international and regional tourism organizations, competitiveness of tourism destinations, global trends, opportunities and challenges, the economic, socio-cultural and environmental impact of the industry. Global Code of Ethics for Tourism will also be examined.

title: Food and Beverage Management
requirements: For students in MSc in Management of Real Estate and Hospitality Assets
description: This course is designed to provide students with skills and knowledge to lead a food service related business efficiently and effectively. Topics include market research and positioning, concept development, ownership structure, entrepreneurial and service mindset, menu design and engineering, global sourcing and ethical procurement practices, food and beverage cost control, yield management, staffing, and physical facilities planning. Contemporary challenges and trends in the food and beverage industry will be addressed.

title: Hospitality Organizational Behavior
requirements: For students in MSc in Management of Real Estate and Hospitality Assets
description: This course introduces the field of organizational behavior from a hospitality perspective. Spanning three general levels, this course will cover the following topics: at the individual level – personality, attribution, value, learning, stress and well being; at the interpersonal and group level – work team, leadership, power and politics, conflict and negotiation; and at the organizational level – structure, culture and organizational change. Through in-class exercises, case discussions and assignments, the students will establish an in-depth understanding of the dynamic of group behavior within organizational settings and enable the application of such knowledge to the management of hospitality organizations.

title: Revenue Management
requirements: For students in MSc in Management of Real Estate and Hospitality Assets
description: This course helps students learn how to apply the principles of revenue management effectively as they apply to the hospitality industry by following the concept of allocating the right type of capacity to the right kind of customer at the right price so as to maximize revenue. Focus is placed on the integration of revenue management techniques with information technology, internal management issues, and external marketing concerns. Topics include theories on revenue management, forecasting, overbooking, group decisions, and management and marketing issues. Students will be exposed to how hospitality organizations use revenue management technique to determine their pricing strategy to maximize their revenue.

title: Global Asset Allocation
requirements: For students in MSc in Management of Real Estate and Hospitality Assets
description: This course provides theoretical foundation for global asset allocation with the applications to real estate securities. Topics include international CAPM and multifactor models in global asset allocation as well as the strategies and tactics of real estate securities portfolio management. Using investment games, students will be introduced to both the conventional wisdom and contemporary methods used in managing a global real estate securities portfolio. Students in this course will have completed (or are concurrently enrolled in) the relevant prerequisite courses in finance, accounting and statistics.

title: Managerial Accounting in Hospitality Industry
requirements: For students in MSc in Management of Real Estate and Hospitality Assets
description: This course aims at building on the principles of financial and managerial accounting as it applies to the hospitality industry. Students will learn how to extract information from Profit & Loss Statement and Balance Sheet to determine the financial health of a hospitality organization. Topics include the Uniform System of Accounts for the Lodging Industry, processing revenue, expenses, assets, liability and equities in financial statements for hospitality companies, financial and managerial accounting analysis, issues and challenges in these industries as well as the costing and pricing. The business ethical standards and practices will be emphasized.

title: Real Estate Valuation
requirements: For students of MSc in Management of Real Estate and Hospitality Asssets
description: This course introduces concept and application of valuation of real estate. Important concepts and techniques of real estate valuation will be covered to demonstrate how these can be applied to a range of property types or for a range of purposes. Topics related to real estate valuation will be covered including the economic forces driving the real estate value in the market, the needs for valuation, valuation methods and their application, investment appraisal and development appraisal. After taking this course, the students are expected to have in-depth understanding of the concept and technique of valuation and demonstrate practical competence in undertaking different types of real estate valuation.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students should be able to: • Understand the economic forces driving the real estate value • Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the purposes for which valuations are undertaken • Comprehend the concepts and techniques for undertaking real estate valuation of individual asset • Apply the valuation principles and techniques through a group project
syllabus: • Microeconomic concepts • Macroeconomic considerations • Valuation mathematics • Valuation methods • Valuation applications • Investment appraisal • Development appraisal
required_readings: Wyatt, P. (2013) Property Valuation, 2nd edition. West Sussex, U.K.: Wiley-Blackwell.
recommended_readings: Appraisal Institute (2013) The Appraisal of Real Estate, 14th edition. U.S.: Appraisal Institute.

title: Facilities Development and Management
requirements: For students of MSc in Management of Real Estate and Hospitality Asssets
description: Facilities management is the total management of all services that support the core business of an organization. It is a process of providing and coordinating effective and efficient services that can be applied holistically to enhance the performance of an organization. Good facilities management does not only benefit an organization, but also its stakeholders such as, among others, staff, clients, and tenants. Strategic facilities development and management emphasizes providing safe, healthy, reliable and productive work environment in a strategic manner to ensure the core business to achieve organizational objectives. This course is designed with a focus on Hong Kong's real estate market. As Hong Kong has an increasing demand for both facilities management and property management professionals, many facilities managers become involved with property management issues or are responsible for managing an organization's property portfolio. Thus, this course will introduce real estate knowledge, business analysis skills and special techniques on both facilities management and property management professionalism. The course aims to ensure students to 1) understand the role of strategic facilities management in the real estate life cycle; 2) develop critical thinking about all facets of facilities management services; 3) master the knowledge of operational level management, including real estate leasing, liabilities and legal issues, maintenance, landlord and tenant relationships, service charges, etc.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students should be able to: • Understand and articulate the role of Facilities Management in the overall competitive strategy of the organization in the context of when, where, what type and on what terms real estate services will be demanded • Recognize the impact of the workplace on organizational productivity • Assess the performance of real estate assets across a wide range of performance criteria with their knowledge of facilities management • Apply the key competencies of a facility manager through problem solving and decision making in various businesses
syllabus: • Introduction of facilities management  • Facilities management strategies • Facilities management planning • The delivery of services • Review of facilities management performance • Real estate and property management • Operational management  • Maintenance management • Managing office workplace • People and organizational capability • Technology, information and data management • Hospitality facilities planning and management

title: Executive Speaker Series and Industry Consulting Studies
requirements: For students of MSc in Management of Real Estate and Hospitality Asssets
description: This course aims to provide an immersive experience for students to integrate theory and practice. The course consists of two parts. Part I is designed as a series of executive speeches. Industry leaders in the hospitality, tourism and real estate sectors in Asia are invited to participate and speak on the investment and development strategies of their companies and the existing and emerging trends, challenges, and opportunities facing their industries. Students are required to research and study the company and the industry prior to engaging the speaker. The executive speaker series provides the students with opportunities to learn leading companies' current strategies and best practices, and gain strategic insights through interacting with the industry leaders. Part II consists of consulting projects conducted by students. Project objectives and contents will be designed by the participating company(ies) and the course instructor(s) collaboratively. The projects will be centered on conducting a strategic diagnosis for the participating company and proposing solutions/actions to improve the company's competitiveness and performance. In addition to the emphasis on companies' operational and financial success, special attention will be placed on the sustainability and integrity issues that are important for companies competing in the hospitality, tourism and real estate industries in Asia. Students learn to apply up-to-date theories and analytical tools and are encouraged to come up with innovative solutions for the participating companies.

title: Retail Management
requirements: For students of MSc in Management of Real Estate and Hospitality Asssets
description: The retail industry is closely related to the hospitality and tourism industry. Hong Kong is a key touristic destination and is renowned for providing visitors with exciting and exceptional products and shopping experiences. This industry is also important in major international tourist hubs including Paris, Milan, London, Tokyo, and New York - cities that are regarded as shopping paradises and attract foreign tourists inflow with various types of pro-retail sales schemes. China is a big market for the retail industry because of its huge population base and recent strategic shift towards recognition of the service industries.The retail industry is a highly competitive industry and there are special management skills and trainings required in order to lead and succeed in the business. It is closely related to real estate asset management, especially for the luxury brand flagship stores, and specialty retail brands like Ikea, for which locating land for its huge Blue Box Ikea stores is critical to its business success.This course examines different types of retailing, future trends in the retailing industry, and the key management skills required for this industry. In addition to retail operations and management practices, the course will also discuss the relations between the retailing industry and the tourism and real estate industries. The course also discusses how retailing businesses use competitive strategies and advanced information technologies to create competitive advantages, and how they manage relationships with stakeholders, including customers, suppliers, and policy makers.

title: Shopping Mall Development and Management
requirements: For students of MSc in Management of Real Estate and Hospitality Asssets
description: Shopping mall is a dynamic business and has been one of the important assets in the investment portfolio. Unlike other real estate assets focusing only on the rental income paid by the tenants, the shopping mall predominantly concerns about the business of the tenants and how to increase their revenue. The shopping mall business thus requires thorough management to attract more customers and to increase the traffic flow. Despite the significance of site selection and financial feasibility, other important factors determining the success of a shopping mall include tenant mix, marketing and promotion, operation and maintenance, as well as asset enhancement. This course introduces theoretical knowledge and concept affecting the development and management of the shopping mall. After taking this course, students should have a good understanding of the shopping mall business and allow them to work in the shopping mall development and management field.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students should be able to: • Describe the fundamental importance of shopping mall business in terms of development and management • Apply theoretical framework to shopping mall business in Hong Kong • Identify underperformed shopping mall and suggest its improvements • Develop creative thinking, self-managed ability, team work spirit, analytical and communication skills through class discussion and project presentation
syllabus: • Overview of shopping mall • Project feasibility and financing of a shopping mall • Planning and design • Expansion and rehabilitation • Tenant mix • Leasing process • Marketing strategy • Operation and maintenance • Future trends
required_readings: Kramer, A. et al. (2008) Retail Development, 4th edition. Washington, D.C.: Urban Land Institute.
recommended_readings: Alexander, A.A. and Muhlebach, R.F. (1992). Shopping Center Management. Chicago: Institute of Real Estate Management.

title: Revitalisation of Historic Buildings
requirements: For students of MSc in Management of Real Estate and Hospitality Asssets
description: Historic buildings bear witness to the development of a city and they are valuable and unique assets of urban community. In recent years, people have grown increasingly aware of the issue of the demolition and redevelopment of historic buildings. New generations are shouldering the responsibilities of inheriting and maintaining the culture of the city in a sustainable manner. This course focuses on historic buildings and sites in relations to their settings and aims to introduce the revitalisation theories, revitalisation policies and revitalisation process. Case studies are used to illustrate revitalisation projects in Hong Kong, Mainland China, Macau and Singapore.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the students will be able to:  • Understand the core concepts and theories of revitalisation; • Understand the value of historic buildings, including their historic value, architectural value and social value; • Understand the reasons behind and benefits of revitalising historic buildings;  • Analyze and evaluate the historic building revitalisation approach and process; and • Generate their own perspectives and interest in the subject of historic building revitalisation.

title: Land Conversion Process and Development Control
requirements: For students in MSc Management of Real Estate and Hospitality Assets
description: Land improvement refers to investments that make land more usable for humans. Prior to the development of its industrial and commercial activities, Hong Kong was once an agrarian society with a large amount of active agricultural land. The growth of Hong Kong’s economy is accompanied with large areas of agricultural land, with fish ponds and farmlands, being developed into other uses. Land conversion process and development control has significant economic and social implications for all stakeholders involved. This course is designed to address two major topics: lease control and statutory control during land conversion and development processes. The course provides a foundation for understanding land development. Landowners and developers of all sizes typically aim to maximize profits, minimize risks and control cash flow. These objectives require landowners and developers to design optimal plans for local markets and meet local legal and administrative requirements and procedures. This course introduces Hong Kong’s land tenure system and development control and helps students understand the geographical characteristics of real estate properties in Hong Kong that have been developed into different uses over time. Students will also learn about the interplay between development processes and local conditions.

title: Real Estate Economics
requirements: For students in MSc Management of Real Estate and Hospitality Assets
description: Real estate, governing one-third of the world’s assets, plays an important role in the capital markets. It is thus crucial to understand how the real estate system works and what economic forces drive the real estate value. In the real estate system, there are two markets (space market and asset market) and one industry (development industry). Space market is essential to the overall real estate system as it governs rents. Changes in rent promptly influence the demand for real estate asset market, and development industry at a later date. This course introduces urban and real estate economics. Urban economics is the primary branch of economics for studying the space market. Topics related to urban economics and real estate space-market analysis will be covered, including four-quadrant model, central place theory, residual theory of land value, the concept of rent, bid-rent analysis, neighborhood life cycle, property life cycle, and demand and supply for real estate space market. After taking this course, students are expected to have in-depth understanding of factors that trigger the functioning of real estate space markets.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students should be able to: • Understand the theories and principles of urban economics that is of paramount importance in making well-informed real estate investment decisions • Comprehend the economic principles and concepts that determine the land value and rent in the city • Apply the principles of land value and rent determinants in conducting the real estate market analysis • Analyze Hong Kong’s and Mainland China’s real estate space markets

title: Planning and Executing Real Estate and Hospitality Projects
requirements: For students in MSc Management of Real Estate and Hospitality Assets
description: The use of projects has been increasing in organizations. A project can be defined as a temporary endeavor undertaken to create a unique product, service, or result. Projects are particularly important for financial success of real estate and hospitality organizations, in which time-sensitive and budget-constrained projects are widely used in planning, developing, financing, evaluating, managing, and marketing business solutions or real estate properties. The abilities to successfully plan and execute projects have become an important leadership competency in the real estate and hospitality industries. To lead a larger organization in these industries, a manager needs to first develop the capabilities to integrate his or her technical, organizational, behavioral, financial, quality, logistical, and informational expertise in completing projects. The objective of this course is to equip students with project planning and execution skills and tools relevant to real estate and hospitality assets. In addition to discussing the critical steps in a project (e.g., initiation, plan, budget, schedule, monitoring, control, performance evaluation, and risk management), the course also emphasizes how organizational factors (structure, strategy, and culture) and industry-specific standards and practices affect project results. Experiential learning activities such as real-world group projects from the real estate/hospitality fields, active case discussions, and business examples will be offered along with lectures for the purpose of enhancing students’ conceptual understanding and practical skills.
outcome: Upon completing this course, students should be able to • Understand a project life cycle and describe its key elements, including planning, development, execution, and closing • Understand and apply tools, techniques, and skills in scheduling, budgeting, resource allocation, cost control, quality assurance, risk management, and project delivery • Identify and use key performance metrics for project success • Describe how to manage stakeholder interests and relationships in each stage of project management  • Understand how organizational structure, strategy, culture, and resources facilitate (or hinder) successful project management  • Engage and lead effective project management teams
syllabus: • Organization strategy and project selection • Organizational structure and culture  • Defining the project  • Estimating project times and costs  • Developing a project plan  • Managing risk  • Scheduling resources and costs  • Being an effective project manager  • Managing project teams  • Progress and performance measurement and evaluation  • Project closure
required_readings: Larson, E., & Gray, C. (2018). Project Management: The Managerial Process (7th ed.). McGraw-Hill.

title: Research in Hospitality, Tourism and Real Estate
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Business Administration
description: This course is designed to acquaint students with research and writings regarding the current issues in service industries. Students are made aware of the contemporary issues and are willing to think about his/her solutions in a logical sequence. Seminars will cover a wide variety of subjects related to issues and opportunities in the organization, administration and evaluation of existing and challenging practices, concepts and theories in the management distinctive to that of hospitality, tourism and service. Emphasis will place on the identification of relevant interdisciplinary paradigms and theory and the evaluation of social science research. Seminar will also cover topics related to methodologies and techniques for analysis, reporting and critiquing hospitality issues using advanced concepts and quantitative methods in the scientific investigation of problems related to hospitality.
outcome: After completing this course, students should have acquired the following professional skills: (1) Students will demonstrate comprehensive knowledge related to different theories and concepts in the field of Hospitality, Tourism, and Real Estate Research (2) Students will demonstrate the ability to define, identify, and evaluate important research questions in the field of Hospitality, Tourism, and Real Estate. (3) Students will apply analytical and quantitative skills to analyze and formulate business research problems in the field of Hospitality, Tourism, and Real Estate. (4) Students will demonstrate the ability to write a research paper in the field of Hospitality, Tourism, and Real Estate.

title: Independent Study
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Business Administration
description: Each student will be assigned a research project guided and supervised by the course instructor. It provides an opportunity for both the instructor and student to work together and thus enable them to have mutual understanding. It also aims to further the student's experience in undertaking research work.
